The increased global energy demand resulting from population growth and the use of fossil fuels has led to environmental issues such as greenhouse gas emissions. This review focuses on Dry Reforming of Methane (DRM) technology that has the potential to convert methane and carbon dioxide (two major greenhouse gases) into syngas which is a base material for various chemical and fuel products. It is virtually impossible to perform the DRM reaction on an industrial scale if there is no efficient, low-cost and highly resistant to deactivation catalyst. This review gives information on the recent development in efficient and robust DRM catalysts following a brief discussion on the thermodynamics and the mechanisms involved in the DRM process. The paper also classifies the main types of catalysts based on the supporting material for supported catalysts and reduced solid solution catalysts in addition to identifying significant performance improvement factors. It is to give an insight into the catalytic interactions and to help in the improvements of the catalyst stability and activity concerning issues such as coking and sintering. In the last part of the article, the important parameters affecting the catalyst design discussed and the authors’ opinion on the future advancements in this field have been portrayed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane Catalyst Catalyst support Sintering Carbon deposition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the recent years, rapid growth of population has led into an explosion in the fuel demand. The extensive burning of fossil fuels results in the increased atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), thus forming an essential eco driver for global climatic change. Fossil fuels represent over 90 % of the global energy demand [1–3]. The relentless extraction and consumption of these fuels over centuries have led to their inevitable depletion. Burning these fuels such as coal, natural gas, and oil, along with solid waste, trees, and other organic substances has released greenhouse gases (GHGs) like CO2 and CH4 into the atmosphere [4–6]. A depiction of greenhouse gases emission and concentration in different decades are summarized in Fig. 1 . CO2 and CH4 are the main GHGs responsible for global warming and climate change, contributing approximately 81 % and 16 %, respectively, to these phenomena. CO2 has a more prolonged impact, while CH4, although shorter-lived, has more than 80 times the warming potential of CO2 in the first two decades after being released into the atmosphere [7–9]. In this scenario, the technology of Dry Reforming of Methane (DRM) offers an excellent opportunity to tackle both problems simultaneously. The DRM process converts CO2 and CH4 into syngas, a mixture of H2 and CO in an approximate ratio of 1:1, highly favorable for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) to prepare value-added chemicals. A schematic of different routes of syngas utilizations in the production of high-value compounds is presented in Fig. 2 . The overall equation for the DRM reaction is as follows: (1) CH4+CO2 → 2H2+2CO ΔH298K = +247 kJ/mol It is an endothermic reaction and requires a considerable energy input, typically carried out at a high temperature of 700–1000 °C. This makes the produced syngas a building block for many chemicals and fuels, thus indicating the industrial importance of DRM. The DRM process has been accomplished up to the present time by several methods, including thermal catalytic processes, photo-assisted reactions, plasma-assisted processes, solid oxide fuel cells, and chemical looping, among others. Between all the different techniques, thermal catalytic DRM has been the most widely studied and with the least industrial application [10,11]. The practical implementation of thermal catalytic DRM calls for developing efficient, stable, and cost-effective devised catalysts. Nickel (Ni)-based catalysts supported on aluminum oxides, which are active and have a low price, are primarily used in industrial processes. Unfortunately, these catalysts are affected by sintering and coking, which finally decreases their performance over time [12]. Recent studies addressing these challenges has focused on designing catalysts with a high resistance to sintering and carbon deposition. The significant strategies include designing bimetallic catalysts, advanced support materials, and a new synthetic approach. Bimetallic catalysts with Ni and cobalt (Co) as metal components have been shown to improve performance due to metal synergy. Co offers an even more significant number of redox properties, which improve the resistance of the catalyst to coking and its operational life. More modern supports include cerium oxide (CeO2) and silicon dioxide (SiO2) increase the stability and dispersion of the active metal sites, all with the sintering ability. This has been well described in several review articles on the advancement of DRM catalyst development over the last decade. For instance, advanced techniques and catalyst development were discussed by Lavoie [13]. in 2014, and Usman et al. [14]. in 2015, with reviews about the effect of process parameters on catalytic performance. In this regard, Bian et al. [15]. in 2017, undertook reviews of bimetallic nickel-based catalysts, Abdullah et al. [16]. in 2017 did a cpmprehensive review on Ni-based catalysts until that time, Jang et al. [17]. in 2018 have provided an understanding of catalytic properties and their relationship with the perfomance of them in designing a suitable catalyst for the DRM process. Li et al. [18]. in a 2021 published review, accurately pointed on the importance and efficacy of reduced solid solution catalysts. le Sach´e et al. [19] in 2022 dived in catalyst design and identifying challenges for industrial implementation. They aimed to inspire further development of highly efficient catalysts and alternative approaches to improve the process's energy efficiency and stability. Alhassan et al. [20] in 2023, in a more recent work, gave us an outlook of emerging trends, current challenges, and future perspectives. The number of published works in the area of DRM is reported in Fig. 3 . The reactor design is beyond the scope of this review; therefore, the reactors discussed are primarily fixed bed or fluidized bed reactors. A few studies have employed Chemical Looping Reforming (CLR), which is mentioned to provide a contrast with the two conventional reactor technologies. The objective of this review is to systematically encompass and categorize, all eligible support materials employed in the design of catalysts for the DRM reaction along with the special catalytic structures (e.g. MgO based, pyrochlores, spinel oxides and perovskites) and also the cases created from solid solution media. Furthermore, it investigates recent advancements in DRM catalysts, as detailed in numerous scholarly publications. This methodical analysis aims to enhance our understanding of the various support materials and catalytic methodologies, thereby facilitating the development of more efficient and sustainable DRM processes. By employing a comprehensive and chemically nuanced approach, this review seeks to provide valuable insights into the interactions and properties of catalytic supports, promoting advancements in catalyst stability, activity, and resistance to deactivation mechanisms such as coking and sintering. 2 ABCs of DRM 2.1 Thermodynamic of DRM The DRM reaction is a relatively slow reaction that requires a great quantity of energy in the form of heat to break apart the CO2 and CH4 molecules. One reason for DRM's high heat demand, is that the energies for CH4 and CO2 dissociation is very high (439.3 and 750 KJ.mol-1, respectively) [18]. This makes DRM a time-consuming reaction in terms of conversion. Another problem with the DRM is the side reaction occurrence. Below are Eqs. (2)–(9) that introduce side reactions of the DRM reaction. (2) CO2 + H2 → CO + H2OΔH298K = +41 kJ/mol (3) 2CH4 + 2CO2 → C2H4+2CO + 2H2OΔH298K = +284 kJ/mol (4) 2CH4 + CO2 → C2H6 + CO+ H2OΔH298K = +106 kJ/mol (5) 2CO → C + CO2ΔH298K = −172.4 kJ/mol (6) CO2 + 2H2 → C + 2H2OΔH298K = −90 kJ/mol (7) 3H2O + CH3OCH3 →2CO2+ 6H2ΔH298K = +136 kJ/mol (8) CH3OCH3 + H2O → 2CO+ 4H2ΔH298K = +204.8 kJ/mol (9) CH4 → C + 2H2ΔH298K = +75 kJ/mol One of the most important side reactions is the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS) (Eq. (2)). This reaction increases the CO2 conversion, resulting in a degraded H2/CO ratio below 1 [21]. The ideal conditions for achieving high equilibrium conversion for both reactants, could be ascribed to high temperature (>1000 K) and atmospheric pressure [19]. RWGS reaction is more likely to occur in a high temperature same as DRM which make a problem for obtaining unity H2/CO ratio. The reason that the ideal H2/CO ratio is 1:1, is that it fits with downstream processes like Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and methanol production while supporting carbon utilization and economic viability [22]. Equally, a ratio higher than 1 is also unpleasant. It specifies a quicker methane decomposition rate than coke carbon gasification rate which leads to carbon accumulation and Therefore catalyst deactivation [23]. Aside from methane dissociation, Boudard reaction (Eq. (5)) is another problematic side reaction, also known as CO disproportionation reaction. Research works indicate that while CH4 decomposition reaction take place at temperatures greater than 550 °C, the Boudard reaction occurs at temperature around 700 °C [24]. Therefore, carbon formation take place in the temperature range of 550–700 °C and the optimal temperature for DRM would be 870–1040 °C [21]. For the Gibbs free energy minimization, several studies used different parameters, such as temperature [25], pressure [26,27] and CO2/CH4 feed ratio. Except for the Boudard reaction and hydrogenation of CO2, all reactions are extremely endothermic, which can be related to the high stability of their reactants. When the reaction temperature is increased to about 700 °C, DRM Reaction becomes thermodynamically favorable. Note to be remembered is that DRM and methane cracking reach equilibrium temperatures approximately 150 °C and 250 °C lower than the equilibrium temperature of the RWGS reaction, respectively. The Boudard reaction, at low temperatures, was spontaneous, and equilibrium was achieved at 700 °C, but above that temperature, the reaction is unfavorable. In brief, the optimal temperature for DRM occurrence is above 700 °C, with a lower possibility of Boudard, methane cracking, and RWGS reactions occurrence. The feasibility of carbon gasification by CO2 or steam is also significantly improved in this temperature range. Based on a study by Nikoo and Amin [2], Four carbon formation reactions were considered for DRM: hydrogenation of CO2 (Eq. (6)), hydrogenation of CO, methane decomposition(Eq. (9)), and Boudard reaction. At CO2/CH4 ratios less than 1, methane decomposition is key factor for carbon deposition, leading to increased H2 and constant solid carbon even at high temperatures. Conversely, at CO2/CH4 ratios greater than 1, hydrogenation reactions dominate, reducing carbon formation and CO2 conversion at higher ratios. An optimal syngas production condition, with H2/CO ratio of 1, is at temperatures above 1173 K and CO2/CH4 ratio of 1, achieving over 98 % CO2 conversion and minimal carbon formation. In addition to these conventional carbon formation pathways, recent work by Al-Fatesh et al. [28]. provides further insight into carbon management during DRM. The researchers have investigated a Ni-Ce/W-Zr catalyst through which they discovered that oxygen vacancy generation occurs sequentially for automated gasification of coke products in situ. The mechanism operates to improve the CO2 activation process for effective carbon gasification and simultaneously reduces carbon accumulation which supports prolonged catalyst stability (up to 100 h). Research findings highlight the need for catalyst optimization to achieve balanced carbon formation and gasification reactions which strengthens the thermodynamic analysis presented earlier.In another work, Marinho et al. [29] showed that Ni nanoparticles embedded in CeZrO₂, synthesized via a one‐step sol–gel method, reduce carbon deposition in DRM. Enhanced oxygen mobility at 800 °C prevents coke formation, with no carbon detected after 24 h. The analysis of the thermodynamic equilibrium composition for DRM reaction (Fig. 4 ), shows that methane and carbon dioxides are completely converted at the temperature exceeding 800 °C. Carbon deposition mainly takes place at all temperatures but is slowed at high temperatures. According to the literature [19], Steaming and oxygenation of the feedstock further improves the hydrogen generation and the H2/CO ratio in the produced syngas which is favorable for processes with higher hydrogen utilization. Taken together, the plot highlights the importance of operating conditions in enhancing the conversion efficiency of the reactants and tuning the conformation of the resultant syngas in DRM processes. A detailed thermodynamic equilibrium analysis of biogas reforming processes under different feed composition CH4/CO2 ratio, steam and oxygen content can be found in the references [19,30]. Optimal syngas production, with a H2/CO ratio of 1, is achieved at temperatures above 900 °C with a CO2/CH4 ratio of 1. According to the Fig. 4, choosing a CO2/CH4 ratio less than 1 is not recommended due to high carbon formation across the temperature range of 300–1000 °C. These results are in an agreement with the literature. 2.2 DRM mechanism The reaction of CH4 and CO2 to produce syngas requires complex interactions of the molecules with the catalyst. For this reason, studying the DRM mechanism aims to explore the various factors that could increase the effectiveness and the durability of the reaction. One can point out the importance of the catalyst's surface characteristics as they determine the adsorption and activation processes of the reactants. Thus, the nature of the catalyst determines its properties, hence the different mechanisms involved in catalyzing the reaction. Therefore, by studying these pathways and interaction between molecules, it brings the opportunities for improved catalyst design and operating parameters leading to increased conversion and selectivity. This detailed understanding facilitates the carbon formation prevention and catalyst deactivation, which enables the informed design of influential parameters that can maximize the productivity of DRM reaction. Reaction steps of DRM process are illustrated in Fig. 5 . The adsorbed CH₄ undergoes dissociative adsorption, where the CH bonds are broken sequentially. This process typically occurs in four steps which are as followed: • Step 1: CH4* → CH3* + H* • Step 2: CH3* →CH2* + H* • Step 3: CH2* → CH* +H* • Step 4: CH* → C* + H* As mentioned in the literature [31], the rate of methane dissociation reaction increases with an extend in temperature. Currently, there are three identified possible pathways for CO2 dissociation (Fig. 5b). Pathway 1: CO2* → CO* + O* Pathway 2: CO2* +H* → COOH* + * → CO* + OH* Pathway 3: CO2* +H* →HCOO*+ * →CHO*+O* For CO2 dissociation, pathway 1 shows direct dissociation of CO2 adsorbed by the catalyst into CO and O, and the CO2 reaction promoted by catalyst-adsorbed H may be the reason for the existence of pathway 2 and 3. Moreover, the dissociation of CH₄ proceeds via sequential C–H bond breaking, yielding intermediates CH₃*, CH₂*, CH*, and finally C*. These produced species from dissociation of CH4 can be oxidized by the adsorbed O* and OH* [32]. The CO2 dissociative adsorption is usually assumed a fast step. Regarding the surface structure of catalyst, CO2 can adsorb on the active metal on the support in 3 symmetrical directions which is C coordination, CO coordination (a carbon with one oxygen atom adsorbed on the external view of catalyst along with another oxygen atom exposed) and O direction (both oxygen atoms bonding with the support). However, the actual mechanism is more complex than described. Research works show that the adsorption of CO2 can adoptively change with the transition metal species. For example, the CO2* → CO* +O* dissociation as we know it, happens when CO2 is adsorbed on a stable adsorption site. For Fe and Ni, experiments showed that O* is stably adsorbed at a hollow site, a feature of the catalyst's surface which is specific location on a catalyst surface where atoms or molecules can adsorb, and the CO* was adsorbed in either a top or hollow site in Fe and Ni surfaces. But the dissociative CO* and O* species on Pd, Pt, Ag and Au surfaces can't be stably adsorbed [33]. The electron shifts from active metal to CO2 results in increasing CO bond length and CO2- formation. This anion faces three possible pathways; first, it could dissociate into CO and O – on active metal surface. Second, it could participate in an oxidation reaction with oxygen in metal surface and forming CO3 - and CO3 2 - . And lastly, the Disproportionation with CO2 gas molecules to produce CO3 - and CO [18]. CO2 was found to have elevated activation by the adsorbed hydrogen and creating carbonyls through a H-synergy CO2 activation and dissociation operation [34]. There are a wide range of possibilities of different sorts of reaction occurrences with diverse adsorbed species. Adsorbed hydrogen can spillover to the support and enter a reaction with the adsorbed oxygen resulting in formation of hydroxyl groups (Fig. 5c) while Adsorbed oxygen has the potential to migrate to the metal surface, where it oxidizes CHx molecules, resulting in the formation of CHxO species. The presence of water on the surface may also contribute to the favorable conditions for the formation of CHxO species [35]. The CHxO species later dissociate into CO and H2 (Fig. 5d). Recent studies have demonstrated that DRM catalysis heavily relies on the important mechanism of lattice oxygen spillover together with established CH₄ and CO₂ activation pathways. The incorporation of CeO₂-based supports into catalysts enables improved oxygen mobility through the migration of lattice oxygen to active metal surfaces which results in carbonaceous intermediate oxidation and reduced coke formation. The spillover effect functions together with standard CO₂ and CH₄ adsorption to generate CHₓO species while simultaneously improving catalyst longevity and boosting high-temperature syngas production. The support's inherent oxygen vacancies participate directly in the reaction mechanism by providing an alternative carbon removal pathway which enhances the DRM process efficiency [36,37]. The DRM reaction exhibits a bilateral mechanism for either acidic or basic supports. The metallic site activates methane, while the acidic or basic support sites activate CO2. In case of acidic support, CO2 is activated via the surface hydroxyl groups, creating formate species. Instead, for basic supports, the CO2 activation occurs via the formation of oxycarbonates [38]. The unilateral mechanism of the DRM reaction is followed when the active metals are supported on inactive supports. Therefore, the active site accomplishes the activation of all reactants (CH4 and CO2). First, carbon is generated through the dehydrogenation of CH4, followed by the activation of CO2, which reacts with carbon, eventually resulting in the deactivation of the catalyst [39]. As discussed above, the exact mechanism of the DRM reaction is highly dependent on the catalyst on which it takes place. The features of the catalyst that have the greatest impact on the mechanism are activity and selectivity [40], surface properties [41], structural properties [42], stability and durability [43], and support materials [44]. This is demonstrated in the comprehensive review by Al-Fatesh et al. [45], in which they analyzed eight active metals, twelve supports, and thirty-five promoters in relation to catalyst performance and the DRM mechanism. Table 1 provides a summary of how La2O2CO3, Ni3GaC0.25 and PdAcCeO2 catalyst systems affect the DRM reaction mechanism. The DRM catalytic performance depends highly on metal cluster dimensions and arrangements since supported metal clusters display structure-sensitive behaviors across nanoscale to atomic scales. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) benefit from maximum metal-support interaction that produces special coordination environments which support effective CO₂ activation and restrict CH₄ dehydrogenation pathways. Metal dimers and small clusters with 2–10 atoms show intermediate catalytic properties by combining support-modified electronic features with necessary metallic properties needed for activating CH bonds. The surface properties of metal nanoparticles larger than 1 nm tend to resemble bulk metallic features while corner and edge sites function as fundamental active centers during DRM. The reaction mechanisms described previously (Steps 1–4 for CH₄ and Pathways 1–3 for CO₂) show different reaction efficiencies based on cluster size because SACs prefer CO₂ activation through Pathway 2 using COOH* hydrogen formation yet larger clusters enable direct CO₂ dissociation (Pathway 1). The rate-limiting step in CH₄ activation switches from Step 1 CH bond breaking on big particles to Step 2–3 dehydrogenation processes occurring on smaller clusters and isolated atoms. The structure sensitivity of DRM catalysis creates apparent contradictions in literature regarding catalyst optimization because the metal cluster size and support interaction work with the oxidation state to achieve the best balance between activity and selectivity and resistance to carbon deposition. 3 Catalyst types in DRM There are different approaches for classification of catalysts used in the DRM reaction, each with its logic and basis. For example, one common method is founded on the active metal used in the catalyst structure, leading to a division into precious metal catalysts (Pt, Rh, Pd) and non-precious metal catalysts (Ni based) catalysts [46]. Another route of categorization is the method of reducing the catalyst precursor. Hydrogen reduction entails the process of using hydrogen gas to reduce the metal catalyst precursor. Thermal reduction involves the use of high temperatures in an inert or reducing atmosphere to achieve the aforementioned result. Chemical reduction uses reducing agents such as hydrazine or sodium borohydride to reduce metal precursors and chemicals and permits a broad range of reduction conditions besides the catalyst characteristics. Another approach for the classification of catalysts is based on the catalytic mechanism. Categorizing catalysts by their catalytic mechanism includes identifying the types of active sites present. Bifunctional catalysts contain two types of active sites, namely metal and acid/base sites that can promote the various steps of the DRM reaction. Single-site catalysts have clearly defined and separate active sites, which result in high selectivity and efficiency in catalysis. Catalysts for DRM reaction can also be classified according to preparation method. Commonly utilized catalyst preparation methods among literature, involves impregnation, co-precipitation and sol-gel method. Impregnation, where the active metal is added to the support by immersing the support in a solution containing the metal precursor. Co-precipitation is a method where both the active phase and support material are precipitated from a solution and therefore the two are well mixed. The sol-gel method is a chemical technique where the catalyst is prepared from a colloidal solution, which undergoes a gelation process, thus enabling the fine-tuning of the catalyst composition and morphology. Various categorizing approaches exist and still are being developed. For the integrity of this work with reliable literature, we place criterion on the correlation between the active species and the substrate before reduction. Due to this criterion, we classify the DRM catalysts into two categories: supported and reduced solid solution catalysts. Supported catalysts (Fig. 6 a), as their name designates, the active constituent is fixed on a supporting material that does not include the active metal phase itself. These catalysts benefit from the stability and surface area provided by the support material, which can enhance the distribution of the active phase and improve the overall catalytic performance. On the other hand, a reduced solid solution catalyst (Fig. 6b) is formed by incorporating active species into an oxide solid solution. In this type of catalyst, the active metal is present in both the catalyst surface and the supporting background. This dual presence can facilitate better interface between the active phase and the reactants, potentially leading to enhanced catalytic activity and constancy [47]. One of the most significant obstacles in selecting an appropriate catalyst for the DRM reaction is carbon accumulation, which mainly results from methane decomposition. This carbon deposition can severely deactivate the catalyst, reducing its effectiveness over time. Given that DRM requires high temperatures to achieve full conversion, this exacerbates the problem by further accelerating catalyst deactivation [48]. Hence, an appropriate catalyst for the DRM reaction should be able to suppress the formation of carbon thermodynamically and should have an extended lifespan and high stability especially under high temperatures. This remains a challenge in the studies and developments in catalyst design as they strive to improve the ability of the catalyst to resist coking and at the same time, perform optimally. 4 Supported catalysts Since the 1930s, designing and developing supported catalysts have been an endeavor for researchers [49]. When it comes to design of supported catalysts, different factors should be considered for optimal performance of the catalysts. These factors include supporting materials, dispersion of active phase on the support, promoters and the metal-support interactions [50]. In this section, we will discuss the components of a supported catalyst to learn more about their structure. 4.1 Supporting materials The supporting species add certain properties to the catalyst which plays a crucial role in the catalyst performance. Properties such as high surface area, electron mobility, and high metal particle dispersion. It also functions as a surplus reaction site for the catalyst. These qualities are correlated so that an increase in surface area leads to a greater dispersion of the active metallic phase. Usually, when it comes to the excellent surface area, supporting materials such as Silica (SiO2), Ceria (CeO2), and Alumina (Al2O3) are serious candidates. Along with the merits mentioned, these materials also beget a confinement effect. This effect results in superiority for supported catalysts in two ways. Firstly, by controlling the particle size and generating smaller and more uniform active species. Smaller particles show higher surface area and therefore enhances the catalyst activity. Secondly, the support acts as a molecular anchor, stabilizes the active part, and prevents the accumulation and sintering of active species [51]. Since the DRM reaction is a dual functional reaction, which means that CO2 usually gets activated on the support and methane is activated on the active metal site [52], the choice of support is an important step. Studies have shown that along the chosen support, which influences the surface basicity or acidity, coke is formed differently. It either forms through methane decomposition or the Boudouard reaction [53]. Fig. 7 illustrates the materials commonly used as a support and have characteristics such as a porous structure, high surface area, and chemical and thermal stability. The usage and details of these supporting materials will be discussed in the subsequent sections. 4.1.1 DFT studies on metal oxide-supported catalysts for DRM: interface effects and reaction mechanisms Recent density functional theory (DFT) investigations have significantly advanced our understanding of metal oxide-supported catalysts for DRM, revealing the essential role of metal-support interfaces in determining both catalytic activity and carbon resistance. The complexity of these interfaces necessitates atomic-level insights to explain experimental observations and guide catalyst design. Catalytic performance depends heavily on the crystal orientation of oxide supports because different metal-support interactions develop at specific strengths. Using DFT+U calculations Huang et al. [54]. discovered that Ni₁/CeO₂(111) showed −3.76 eV Ni adsorption strength but Ni₁/CeO₂(110) reached −4.82 eV and Ni₁/CeO₂(100) reached −5.43 eV. The CeO₂(100) surface demonstrates maximum anchoring strength because it provides optimal Ni-O interaction conditions. The strength of MSI showed an inverse relationship with methane activation barriers where Ni₁/CeO₂(110) with NiO-4C provided the lowest barrier at 0.37 eV followed by Ni₁/CeO₂(111) at 0.77 eV and Ni₁/CeO₂(100) with the highest barrier at 0.88 eV. The apparent conflict shows that ideal catalytic efficiency depends on MSI which provides strong Ni atom binding while maintaining sufficient active site accessibility and electronic mobility. Analysis of Ni electronic properties through oxygen coordination reaches its peak when researchers introduce oxygen vacancies (VO). The Ni₁/CeO₂(110) surface showed a substantial increase in CH₄ activation barrier from 0.37 eV to 1.09 eV when Ni coordination changed from NiO-4C to NiO-3C-VO. At the same time, CeO₂(111) produced NiO-2C-VO sites which lowered the activation barrier from 0.77 eV to 0.63 eV. The generation of highly unsaturated Ni sites (NiO-1C-VO) on CeO₂(110) produced a remarkable activation barrier of 0.10 eV which proves that exact coordination control enables nearly barrier-free CH activation pathways. Gašparič et al. [55] used density functional theory calculations to understand the mechanistic reasons why Ni/MnxCeO₂ catalysts containing MnOx dopants outperformed Ni/CeO₂ catalysts without dopants. Analysis of vibrational frequencies from their research confirmed that Ni/CeO₂ produced a 2020 cm⁻¹ peak which corresponded to CO bound to metallic Ni. The presence of Mn doping in the system resulted in the disappearance of the Ni oxidation peak. The model compound Ni(111) effectively catalyzes DRM at high temperatures but the 1.31 eV barrier for dehydrogenating CHx to C* was comparable to barriers of productive paths which explains the observed carbon deposition. The model NiO (100) system showed elevated barriers that protected Ni from coking damage. Mn-doping provides beneficial effects because it enhances Ni-O interactions between the metal and support interface which modifies electronic structure to prevent coke formation while maintaining sufficient DRM activity. Research shows that controlled interfacial charge redistribution from dopants allows scientists to adjust Ni oxidation states for achieving optimal activity-stability performance. Jiao & Wang [56] studied the influence of external electric fields (EFs) on Ni₁₆/ZrO₂ catalyst electronic properties for DRM applications. The combined DFT and microkinetic modeling confirmed that tetragonal ZrO₂ allows Ni electrons to transfer to ZrO₂ resulting in an interfacial dipole that reduces CO adsorption strength while improving carbon deposition resistance. Through Bader charge analysis researchers measured ZrO₂'s electron sink properties that stabilized CHO* and COOH* intermediates at the interface. Positive EFs (+0.6 V/Å) enhanced methane activation through barriers reduction of 0.2 eV for CH₄ dehydrogenation and facilitated CHx oxidation processes. At the same time negative EFs (−0.6 V/Å) significantly improved CO₂ dissociation by lowering the activation energy to 0.85 eV. The study through microkinetic modeling revealed CH–O coupling as the principal reaction mechanism on Ni₁₆/ZrO₂ while CH* dimerization (CH* + CH* → C* + H₂) served as the main factor in carbon buildup. The electronic structure-reactivity correlations showed fundamental validity through the preservation of Brønsted–Evans–Polanyi relationship when electric fields were applied to the system. The DFT studies have collectively revealed essential mechanistic information about DRM reactions on supported metal oxide catalysts. The rate-determining transition changes depending on the catalyst composition and structure because Ni₁/CeO₂(111) shows the CH₃* → CH₂* transition as the highest barrier at 0.56 eV while Ni₁/CeO₂(110) exhibits the CH₂* → CH* step as rate-determining with a barrier of 1.09 eV. Huang et al. demonstrated through their work on Ni₁/CeO₂(110) that carbon removal occurs easily through direct bonding between C* carbon deposits and surface lattice oxygen Olat which requires minimal energy barriers amounting to 0.03 eV. The hydrogen spillover effects showed enhanced strength from CeO₂(100) to CeO₂(110) and CeO₂(111), enabling the formation of H₂ and carbon elimination by involving lattice oxygen in the process. The observations of Gašparič demonstrate that H* species perform surface diffusion much faster on metallic Ni surfaces than on oxidized surfaces which explains the performance requirements. The atomic-level study presents specific guidelines which can guide future development of DRM catalysts. The optimal catalyst should possess four critical elements which include balanced metal-support interactions and electronic accessibility and precise metal oxidation control through dopants or electric fields and engineered interfaces that activate methane and carbon dioxide while optimizing oxygen mobility for carbon removal processes. The crystal plane engineering method described by Huang et al. presents a promising method to synthesize single-atom catalysts with controlled MSI which solves both activity limitations and deactivation problems. The electronic structure modification methods proposed by Gašparič et al. and Jiao & Wang establish alternative methods through the combination of dopant introduction and electric field application. The computational investigations prove that metal oxide-supported DRM catalyst development needs atomic-level control of interfacial phenomena because electron transfer dynamics along with coordination environments and oxygen mobility work together to determine performance outcomes. Scientists should focus on fundamental catalyst properties to create systems which solve the persistent DRM process challenge of balancing catalytic activity with carbon resistance. 4.1.2 Silica (SiO2) Silica is widely used as a catalyst support because of its desirable properties, including high surface area, controllable pore size, availability, and chemical inertness [57,58]. It is recognized as a relatively acidic support that affects its selectivity to hydrogen in catalytic reactions. Methane dissociation is a primary process in coke production and hydrogen is typically generated through this process. This pathway is usually regarded as more important than the Boudouard reaction. One of the ways that could be used to reduce coke formation is by reducing the amount of metal that is deposited on the catalyst. Thus, when considering the DRM process, the main focus is to create an effective and low-cost catalyst which can prevent this reaction or lower its rate. Noble metals benefit from high catalytic activity. However, they are expensive, hindering their commercial applications. Therefore, the focus has moved to the investigation of transition metals, especially Nickel. Nickel provides a similar degree of activity to noble metals but at a much lower price, making it a realistic substitute for efficient catalytic processes [59]. However, they suffer from increased carbon deposition compared to noble metals. It becomes even more important when their particle size is large (more than 7 nm) [60]. Since the discovery of ordered mesoporous silica in the early 1990s, it has attracted much interest, although material that makes mesoporous silica was patented in 1970 [61]. However, this discovery was made almost unnoticed until the properties of the material were replicated and made more popular in 1997 [62]. In the case of DRM, due to the slight surface acidity and relative inertness for the silica-based supports, CO2 activation is mostly happening on the active site via either direct dissociation (CO2(ads) ↔ COads + Oads) or hydrogen assisted dissociation (CO2(ads) + Hads ↔ COads + OHads) [63]. Besides the properties like high surface area and adjustable pore size, the fact that it could be prepared in various forms, including rods, powders, and spheres, has made it a subject of interest for use as a catalyst support. Compared to conventional porous silica, in which the pores are randomly distributed, ordered mesoporous silica has well-ordered pore structures. This is because of the nanotemplating method used during synthesis, which allows for good pore distribution and diameter control. This structured porosity helps to improve the utilization of the material in many fields, such as catalysis and drug delivery, by providing uniform and accessible channels for the adsorption of the molecules and the reaction [64]. Over the years, researchers have produced considerable forms of ordered mesoporous silica in various pore structures and particle forms. Kageyama et al. [65] were the first research group to report the use of ordered silica in the catalyzed process of polymer synthesis, and that occurrence paved the way for a new road in the solid-supported catalysts field [66]. Fig. 8 shows some varieties of ordered mesoporous silica, and Table 1 provides a summary of some ordered mesoporous silica and their characteristics. The following sections explore various studies investigating how different preparation techniques, silica-based support structures, and metal-promoter combinations can overcome the limitations of traditional nickel-based catalysts and achieve greater efficiency in the DRM process. Yang et al. [67] prepared Ni-CeO2/SBA-15 catalyst using two different methods. One uses a conventional impregnation method (C suffix), and the other uses a glycine-assisted method (G suffix). XRD and TEM showed that the addition of glycine efficiently promotes the dispersion of NiO and CeO2 in the pores of SBA-15. H2-TPR and XPS findings also validated the establishment of a more robust connection between the metal and support. Moreover, upon introducing glycine, there was a substantial rise in the NixCe1-xOy solid solution content. Concurrently, the Ce3+ concentration surged from 31 % to 49 %, leading to an increase in oxygen vacancies and the creation of active oxygen species which is crucial for activity of catalyst. Consequently, Ni-CeO2/SBA-15-G exhibited superior catalytic performance in the low-temperature DRM tests for the aforementioned reasons. For 20 h test in 600 °C with the GHSV= 600/000 mL/gcat.h, CH4 conversion was 35 % while the conventional method synthesized catalyst had a 17.5 % conversion. The CO2 conversion values were the same. The H2/CO ratio for Ni-CeO2/SBA-15-G was 0.65 while for the conventional one was 0.55. The TGA-DTA test results showed that Ni-CeO2/SBA-15-C went under a significant weight loss (48.5 %) at temperature range of 540–690° which can be obtained from DTA curve that the weight loss originated from the oxidation of carbons deposited. On the other hand, Ni-CeO2/SBA-15-G showed almost no sign of weight lost and no exotherm was detected which means that this catalyst had superb resistance to carbon deposition (Table 2 ). Liu et al. [68] prepared Ni/SBA-15 by two different methods; conventional impregnation method (Ni/SBA-15) and β-cyclodextrin(CD) modified impregnation method (Ni/SBA-15-CD). XRD and TEM studies showed that the Ni particles were smaller, had better spreading on Ni/SBA-CD, and had stronger interaction between Ni and SBA-15. The DRM reactions were carried in 700 °C and time on stream of 50 h. The CH4/CO2 ratio is 1 and GHSV equal to 1.28 × 104 mL g-1 h-1. CO2 conversion for Ni/SBA-15-CD was 95 % while this number for Ni/SBA-15 was 80 %. The CH4 conversion was lower, 82 % for CD catalyst and 68 % for Ni/SBA-15. The use of β-cyclodextrin modification in catalyst preparation significantly improved Ni particle dispersion and catalytic performance in DRM. The higher CO2 conversion of 95 % for Ni/SBA-15-CD as compared to 80 % for the conventional method highlights the importance of support interactions and particle size in defining reaction results. The results of the Raman spectroscopy confirmed the lower carbon deposition on the Ni/SBA-15-CD sample, indicating that preparation methods are key to the degradation of catalysts and their performance by reducing carbon formation. Waris et al. [69] investigated the role of citric acid concentration in a so-called acid-assisted incipient wetness impregnation method. They prepared some variants of Ni/SBA-15 catalysts with citric acid using the method mentioned. They also synthesized Ni/SBA-15 through the conventional impregnation method as a reference. The metal loading was fixed at 7 wt. % for all catalysts. Using the different concentrations of citric acid (the molar concentration of 0.35, 0.7 and 1.4), they produced samples marked as CA0.35, CA0.7, and CA1.4, respectively. The reference sample without the presence of citric acid was marked as CA0. Before putting the catalysts into the reaction, it was reduced at 800 °C for 2 h in a flow of H2/N2=1.4. The DRM reaction was carried out in 700 °C and a flow of 10 vol % of CO2 and CH4 in N2 balance, CH4/CO2 = 1. The GHSV was equal to 96,000 mLg-1h-1 and atmospheric pressure. In the long run, with the TOS of 30 h, CA0.35 had the unsurpassed performance with CO2 conversion of 93 % and CH4 equal to 86 %. The results showed that the addition of citric acid, irrespective of its concentration, led to the formation of well-dispersed nickel particles measuring approximately 4–7 nanometers in Ni/SBA-15 catalysts. The coke formation was also lower for the Ni/SBA-15 that used citric acid during the synthesis stages (∼2–5 mgcoke gcat -1 h-1) compared to the reference Ni/SBA-15 (∼225 mgcoke gcat -1 h-1). The improvement of the catalytic properties and the decrease of coke formation were observed when citric acid was used as synthesis modifier for Ni/SBA-15 catalyst. The great distribution of nickel particles in the range of 4–7 nm confirmed the ability of citric acid to regulate the particle size and enhance permanency of the catalyst. Additionally, the high CO2 conversion rate of 93 % for the CA0.35 catalyst shows how fine a line exists between synthesis conditions and catalytic results. This is exemplified in the study by focusing on different citric acid concentrations which shows that slight differences in the preparation method significantly enhance the catalyst performance. This lays the foundation for more studies on how the support structure, pore size, and nickel dispersion affect the performance of the catalyst especially in the next study on the effects of pore size on DRM performance. Daoura et al. [70] investigated the role of SBA-15′s pore size with a nickel-supported catalyst in the DRM reaction. They prepared three types of catalyst with analogous metal loading (4.2 wt. %) and three types of support with pore sizes of 4, 5, and 7 nm, marked as S4, S5, and S7, respectively. They employed two solvents for the impregnation of support, i.e., the supports were impregnated by an aqueous solution of nickel (II) nitrate in addition to pentane. Subsequently, calcination and reduction in H2 were performed. Then, they observed the tiniest Ni atoms in the Ni/S7 (DNi = 7 nm) and the largest one in Ni/S4 ((DNi = 5.4 nm). They justify this observation because of the availability of larger pores during the nickel impregnation stage. As can be expected, this better metal dispersion led to better catalytic activity and also stability, achieving CH4 conversion from 63 % in Ni/S4 to 75 % in S7 supported one at 650 °C with a GHSV= 72 L.g-1 h-1 in 12 h time on stream. This study emphasized the importance of SBA-15′s pore size on nickel dispersion, revealing that larger pores facilitated better dispersion of Ni particles, which, in turn, improved catalytic activity and stability. To investigate the role of support pore structure on DRM, Zhang et al. [51] prepared Ni/SiO2 catalyst with different support materials. They used three types of supports: the mesoporous silica spheres with inverted conical structure, ordered mesoporous silica (MCM-41) and the commercial silica (SiO2). By maintaining the nickel loading constant at 10 wt. %, through the method of N2 adsorption-desorption, they found out that, after the addition of 10 wt. % NiO, the specific surface area of MSS decreased from 503.6 to 343.9 m2/g while the density reduced by approximately 31 % as shown below; 7 %. MCM-41 declined from 1031.1 to 579.008 m2/g, cut down approximately 43.8 %. Based on these results, it is found that the structure of MSS containing a unique pore size distribution can provide a better environment for a large number of active components. The simultaneous presence of both large and small pores gives rise to a distinctive inverted tapered pore structure, a characteristic further supported by TEM images. The ranking of specific surface area for various supports follows the MCM-41 > MSS > SiO2 order. Regarding pore size, the hierarchy is MSS > MCM-41 > SiO2. As a general rule, a higher specific surface area and pore volume facilitate the scattering of active metals, contributing to enhanced catalytic activity. As the SEM image shows (Fig. 9 a), the synthesized MSSs are uniform and spherical, exhibiting a diameter of 450 nm. Additionally, examination through TEM (Fig. 9b) reveals that the spherical MSS comprises fibers extending outward from the center. This configuration causes a distinctive inverted conical pore structure characterized by a smaller interior and a gradually expanding exterior. This unique pore arrangement enhances the speed of reactant diffusion and promotes the dispersion of nickel. Then, the catalysts underwent a performance evaluation of DRM reaction at 800 °C with the time on stream of 9 h along with a very high GHSV of 144 L.gcat -1.h-1. The results revealed that 10Ni/MSS had the paramount performance, with CH4 conversion of 77.5 % and CO2 conversion of 84.4 %. The study revealed that the 10Ni/MSS catalyst had the top activity and stability because of the inverted conical pore structure that enhanced the Ni particle dispersion, small particle size, low carbon formation, and better diffusion of gases. The MSS structure also hindered the Ni nanoparticle sintering and reduced the activation energy for CH4 and CO2 decomposition; these factors facilitated the superior performance compared to the catalysts with regular and collapsed pore structures. Besides the synthesis method and pore size and structure of support, another factor that can potentially affect the catalyst performance is promoting support with different elements. To study this factor, Mahfouz et al. [72] synthesized Ni-Ru/KIT-6, Ni/KIT-6 and Ru/KIT-6 catalysts with Ni loading fixed in 15 wt. % and Ru on 1wt. %. They created Ni-Ru/Ce-KIT-6 with the same loading amount to examine the Ce promotion effect. After 12 h on stream at 800 °C, for Ni-Ru/KIT-6, CH4 conversion was equal to 65 %, and CO2 conversion was around 75 %. However, CO2 conversion rose to 95 % for the Ce promoted catalyst, and the CH4 conversion reached 97 %. This conversion number was achieved despite the formation of graphitic carbon on the catalyst surface. The amount of carbon deposited on the Ni-Ru/KIT-6 was greatly lower than Ni-Ru/Ce-KIT-6 (5 % compared to 52 %). The substantial accumulation of carbon species results from the intensified catalytic efficiency of catalysts containing cerium. This increases efficiency at times to the extent of producing side products such as carbon from the reactions. Nevertheless, the presence of higher carbon content did not result in catalyst deactivation over the 12 h on stream for the Ni-Ru/Ce-KIT-6 catalyst. This implies that the deposited carbon did not fully surround the Ni sites, thus making them available for the reactants. A more likely elucidation is the regeneration of the active catalytic sites due to constant coke removal through CO2 gasification. Typically, in the process of DRM, it is commonly asserted that the oxygen vacancies facilitated by CeO2 hinder carbon deposition. This is achieved by improving the mobility of surface oxygen and adsorbing species on the catalyst surface [73]. Ruthenium also has a crucial role in catalyzing coke gasification, and the synergetic presence of both ruthenium and cerium has enhanced key properties for DRM reaction. Palanichamy and Sasirekha [74] inspected the effect of the Si/Ti ratio in a Ti-promoted Pt-Ni/Ti-SBA-15 catalyst to investigate a factor beyond the promotion effect on the support. To serve this purpose, they made a series of these bimetallic catalysts with Si/Ti ratios of 10,20,30,50 and 100 and named the Pt-Ni/Ti-SBA-15(x) (X = 10,20,30,50 and 100). In an eight hour time at 700 °C DRM reaction with the GHSV= 36 L.gcat -1.h-1, Pt-Ni/Ti-SBA-15(10) had the superlative performance. The CH4 conversion for this catalyst was 84 %, and the CO2 conversion was equal to 91 %. For comparison, the Pt-Ni/SBA-15 catalyst had a CH4 conversion of 60 % and a CO2 Conversion of 55 %. All other catalysts with a Si/Ti ratio other than 10 had inferior performance compared to Pt-Ni/Ti-SBA-15(10), as presented in Fig. 10 . This improvement stems from increased metal-support interaction, surface acidity, dispersion of active metals, and a modification in the synergistic effect of the bimetallic Pt-Ni system. The Si/Ti ratio study in this context offers a different perspective in the promotion of catalyst support where the performance is highly dependent on support composition. In the case of Pt-Ni/Ti-SBA-15(10) catalyst, the CH4 and CO2 conversion values are 84 % and 91 % respectively, which clearly suggesting that the Si/Ti ratio needs to be optimized to improve the interaction between metal and support. This finding again emphasizes the function of support materials not only as carriers but as performing agents. Based on this understanding, the subsequent research should focus on exploring the interactive roles of other metal-support combinations to enhance the DRM performance and stability. The key to achieve better performances of silica-supported catalysts are promoters. Incorporating various promoters to the silica-supported catalyst can benefit the overall catalyst system by enhanced catalytic activity and stability, improved resistance to coke deposition, better metal-support interactions, enhanced CO2 activation and modification of surface properties. These interesting advantages have prompted researchers to seek the impact of different promoters on silica-supported catalysts. In 2019, Németh et al. [75] conducted a study to realize how indium (In) promotion on Ni/SiO2-supported catalyst inhibits carbon deposition. Their primary results revealed that In dilutes Ni ensembles and also enriched the electron density of Ni. As a results, the carbon deposition reduced by 84.21 % when In were used as a promoter on the Ni/SiO2-supported catalyst. In the same year, Da Costa et al. [76] shifted their focus on yttrium-promoted Ni/KIT-6 mesoporous silica for DRM reaction. The sought to answer how different yttrium loadings (4,8,12 wt %) influences Ni dispersion, reducibility, and resistance to carbon deposition during DRM. In their best scenario (8 wt % Y promotion), they achieved 66.1 % and 72.3 % conversion rates for CH4 and CO2 respectively. Additionally, a 45 % lower carbon formation were reported when yttrium was promoted. They attributed these results with enhanced NiO reducibility and improved Ni dispersion within KIT-6′s pores. The benefits of promoters were also evidenced by the work of Sellam et al. [77]. They innovatively used perovskite material of LaNiO3 as the promoter in a kaolin-driven silica-supported catalyst. In search for effect of LaNiO3 as promoter, they concluded that 40LaNiO₃/SiO₂ catalyst exhibited superior catalytic performance, attributed to small Ni particle size (15 nm), high dispersion, and enhanced reducibility. This catalyst achieved CH₄ and CO₂ conversions of approximately 50 % and 65 %, respectively, at 800 °C, with a H₂/CO ratio near 0.8. Among the most recent works, the work of Singh et al. [78] is noticeable. They investigated the design of boron-promoted Ni/SBA-15 catalysts to study how boron doping outperforms the catalyst without promotion. The study synthesized catalysts with varying boron loadings (1–5 wt %) and concluded that 2 % boron loading optimized catalytic activity, achieving 90 % CH₄ conversion and 92 % CO₂ conversion, while reducing carbon deposition from 14 % (unpromoted catalyst) to 1.3 % (promoted catalyst). This is because, boron dual function which are 1) formation of B-OH species that gasify carbon intermediates and 2) reducing Ni crystalline size (from 11.9 nm to 14.5 nm) which increases active site accessibility. In 2024, Mosaad Awad et al. [79] integrated La₂O₃ into the silica matrix as a promoter, enhancing surface basicity (evidenced by CO₂-TPD). As a result of La2O3 reaction with CO2, La2O2CO3 intermediates form which suppresses coke formation. In their optimal case, NSLF-15 achieved 87 % CH₄ conversion and 86.7 % CO₂ conversion at 750 °C, with negligible deactivation over 28 h. The same research group [80] extended their research query by investigating the role of metal oxide promoter, ZnO, within a silica framework (SZF) while optimizing Ni loading (3–20 wt %). Key findings revealed that incorporating ZnO into the fibrous silica structure strengthened metal-support interaction (SMSI), stabilized Ni nanoparticles, and minimized carbon deposition by enhancing CO₂ activation. Among the catalysts, NSZF-10 (10 wt % Ni) demonstrated exceptional performance, achieving 82 % CH₄ and 74 % CO₂ conversions at 750 °C over 40 h, with a stable H₂/CO ratio (∼1) and only 0.16 % carbon deposition. In summary, the reviewed literature clearly demonstrates that promoter incorporation is pivotal in enhancing silica-supported catalysts. By optimizing metal dispersion, strengthening metal–support interactions, and significantly reducing carbon deposition, promoters such as indium, yttrium, LaNiO₃, boron, La₂O₃, and ZnO markedly improve catalytic activity and stability. These studies collectively highlight the transformative impact of promoter selection on catalyst performance, guiding future innovations in catalyst design. Table 3 provides a comparative overview of the most significant and recent research works that has employed silica as a catalyst support in DRM reactions. This compilation emphasizes silica's critical role in improving catalytic efficiency and stability, underscoring its vital contribution to the designing a capable catalyst for DRM reaction. 4.1.3 Zirconia Zirconia (ZrO₂) has emerged as a promising supporting material for catalysts used in heterogeneous reactions. This supporting material benefits from several features that favor the DRM reaction occurrence, making it a paramount candidate as a supporting material in catalysis design for the DRM reaction. Firstly, zirconia has a high surface area (∼64.7 m²/g), which benefits the uniform dispersion of active sites and metals. This uniform dispersion minimizes particle accumulation and reduces the risk of sintering. Secondly, zirconia is known for its ability to form oxygen vacancies. These oxygen vacancies positively impact CO₂ activation, the reducibility of the catalyst, and coking resistance. Lastly, the tunable acid-base properties of zirconia provide better selectivity control of the reaction. To this end, there has been extensive research on this supporting material. A good portion of the literature has focused on how different promoter/zirconia-based support interactions perform with the objective of enhancing DRM reaction productivity. These researches have either tested different promoters on a zirconia-based support or a promoter on different zirconia-based supports. In the case of varying promoters on the same support, Al-Fatesh et al. [81] investigated how Ca, Cr, Ga and Gd promoters affect Ni-based catalysts that use lanthana-zirconia (La₂O₃-ZrO₂) as the support material. By combining Cr with Ni-La₂O₃-ZrO₂ catalysts researchers achieved maximum hydrogen yield stability of approximately 79 % over 33 h of reaction time through the development of Ni-Cr interaction species that broadened CH₄ decomposition sites and chromate species that enabled carbon oxidation. In another study, Kasim et al. [82] studied the impact of ceria loading on Ni/La₂O₃-ZrO₂. Using a wet impregnation method, the authors synthesized catalysts with varying ceria loadings (0–5 wt %). Their finding was that the optimal ceria loading was 2.5 wt %, which culminated in 86 % and 91 % conversion rates for CH₄ and CO₂, respectively. Inspired by this study, Patel et al. [83] performed like research utilizing WO₃-ZrO₂-supported Ni catalysts on different support. The research team found that Ni/WO₃-ZrO₂ with 2.5 wt % ceria reached an outstanding 78 % H₂ yield while showing stable performance during 420 min of reaction time. The researchers attributed the improvement in carbon deposit oxidation to this effect. The study of promoter effects on zirconia-supported catalysts for DRM reaction requires detailed understanding because it helps reveal the best operational parameters. To this end, the research continues with Khatri et al. [84]. The researchers examined how DRM reaction performance changes when using nickel-based catalysts with different amounts of ceria (1–5 wt %) supported on phosphate-zirconia (PZr). The optimal performance was reached with a 3 wt % ceria loading (10Ni3Ce/PZr) which produced 97 % H₂ yield with an H₂/CO ratio of ∼1 and maintained stability for 440 min on stream. Mobile lattice oxygen enhancement enabled the catalyst to break down coke while maintaining its operational effectiveness. Driven by the same research question, Patel et al. [85] focused on the impact of yttria (Y₂O₃) loading on zirconia-supported nickel catalysts in the DRM reaction. The Ni-15Y-ZrO₂ composition reached the maximum stable hydrogen yield of 67.5 % which decreased gradually to 63.7 % during a 420 min study period because its strong basic sites and oxygen vacancies and mobile lattice oxygen enabled effective CO₂ adsorption and carbon oxidation. In recent years, some researchers have focused on strontium as a promoter over zirconia-based supports for DRM catalysts. Since strontium is less expensive compared to its competitors, it becomes even more important, as the ultimate optimal catalyst should be economical as well— a key element for commercialization. To address this, Acharya et al. [86] analyzed the promotional effects of Sr on Ni-based catalysts which use WO₃ + ZrO₂ as support. The researchers studied how different Sr doping levels affected the yield of H₂ on this support system. The H₂ yield reached its peak level at 57 % after 470 min when 2 wt % Sr was added to Ni/WO₃ + ZrO₂ due to better Ni site metal stability and denser bidentate CO₂-adsorbed species that boost CO₂ activation. To extend their study, Elnour et al. [87] examined the same catalyst system proposed by Acharya et al. However, they concentrated on overall catalytic performance with an emphasis on increasing methane conversion and improving catalyst stability. The optimal Sr loading was the same (2 wt %), and the CH₄ conversion was reported to increase from 60.25 % to 65.48 %. This is because Sr²⁺ stabilized the Ni particles, improving the overall performance of the catalyst. In conclusion, the unique properties of zirconia consisting of high surface area and inherent oxygen vacancies together with adjustable acid-base characteristics explain why it dominates DRM catalyst design. The research demonstrates that promoter combinations including Cr and ceria and yttria and strontium with zirconia produce exceptional catalytic outcomes when promoter amounts are perfectly adjusted. The research shows both the strategic benefit of zirconia-based supports in DRM technologies and suggests new methods for optimization which will help advance commercial DRM technology adoption. 4.1.4 Zeolites From the standard definition for zeolites, a crystalline microporous aluminosilicate material, one can deduce that it has a high porosity. These materials are formed by a network of channels and coops developed by interrelated alumina (Al2O3) and silica (SiO2). These supports are present in both acidic and basic forms, but acidic ones have gained more applications. They possess a high ion exchangeability without alteration in their structure and excellent hydrothermal stability that qualifies them for severe conditions of reactions such as DRM. Acidic sites in zeolites are generally classified into Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites. Brønsted acid sites are involved in the process as proton donors and can be symbolically represented by the hydroxyl group, while Lewis acid sites act as electron pair acceptors and can be represented by an unsaturated metal. Adding metal cations can cause changes in the surface acidity of zeolite, which leads to the formation of new sites. The incorporation of metals can reduce the number of Brønsted acid sites while at the same time generating new Lewis acid sites [88,89]. One of the major problems with employing zeolites for catalytic support in the DRM reaction condition is that due to it is microporous nature, it confronts a rapid deactivation, primarily when Ni is used as the active metal phase, which is associated with intense deposition of coke in the cage of catalyst [90]. Different types of zeolites have been used for catalyst support for the DRM reaction, including Zeolite Y, Beta, and ZSM-5 [91–93]. Among these, ZSM-5 (Zeolite Socony Mobil-5) is extensively researched among zeolites, and it is not unjustified because results in the literature show that it shows promising qualities for CO2 reforming of methane reaction. Jeong et al. [94] inspected the Ni/HY catalyst and the effect of promoters such as Mg and other elements such as Mn, K, and Ca. during a 72 h time on stream at 700 °C. The hierarchy of the catalysts in term of CH4 conversion were in the order of Ni-Mg/HY > Ni-Mn/HY > Ni- Ca/HY > Ni/HY > Ni-K/HY. The reason for this order was related to the fact that carbon deposition during methane reforming with carbon dioxide can result from either extensive methane decomposition or CO disproportionation processes typically favored by large nickel ensembles. However, introducing basic oxides has been suggested to enhance the electron density of nickel, thereby diminishing its propensity for extensive methane decomposition. Ni-Mg/HY, the best catalyst for this group, demonstrated high stability during the 720 h test. While it was ascertained that the sample had endured 21wt. % weight loss, this was not followed by a corresponding decline in catalytic performance. Miskan et al. [91] examined the efficiency of Ni on fibrous zeolite Y(Ni/FHY) in the DRM reaction at 800 °C and 30 h time on stream. Compared to conventional Ni/HY, it has performed much better in conversion and H2 yield. For example, hydrogen yield with Ni/FHY is about 76 % compared to 60 % with Ni/HY. As demonstrated in Fig. 11 , Due to the fibrous nature of FHY, the access to distribute NiO was better than the conventional structure, leading to better NiO dispersion and interaction at the metal-support interface. In addition, the increased values of the alkalinity and reducibility of Ni/FHY played a major role in the stability of the catalyst and the ability to avoid coke formation during the 30 h reaction period. Lee et al. [107] implemented beta-type zeolite for catalytic purposes in the DRM reaction. It was less promising than other types of zeolites. For the Ni/BEA catalyst, CH4 and CO2 conversion were barely attained at 50 % and 60 %, respectively. Catalyst promotion also had no positive influence on the conversion of reactants. The results deteriorated with an increase in time on stream. Because of the similarity between catalysts synthesized using ZSM-5 and for better juxtaposition with different works accomplished with this type of zeolite, the results and reaction conditions were summarized in Table 4 . To clarify the role of promoters in the commonly used Ni/ZSM-5, Zhang et al. [108] synthesized Ni-Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst via impregnation method. Mo's inclusion facilitates the maintenance of a higher proportion of metallic nickel (Ni0) within the Ni-Mo alloy. It augments the adsorption capabilities of both CH4 and CO2, thereby favorably influencing the DRM reaction kinetics. With the help of in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), it was observed that the NiMo amalgam facilitates a more proficient DRM pathway, effectively activating CH4 and CO2. Furthermore, in situ Raman and in situ XRD analyses demonstrated that Mo species immobilized on zeolite substrates induced distinctive transformations between MoOx species and oxycarbide/carbide species, thereby enabling dynamic carbon elimination. These findings elucidate the heightened catalytic efficacy and stability of the newly developed Ni-Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts, which can be attributed to the elevated content of metallic Ni, the optimization of catalytic pathways via formate intermediates, and the distinctive MoOx ↔ MoCxOy redox sequence conducive to carbon removal during DRM. The work of Hambali et al. [116], also highlighted the role of different promoters like Mg, Ca, Ta, and Ga in enhancing the catalytic activity. The sequence of catalytic activity is as follows: Ni/ZSM-5 < Ni-Ga/ZSM-5 < Ni-Ca/ZSM-5 < Ni-Mg/ZSM-5 < Ni-Ta/ZSM-5. The results showed that the reducibility of NiO on Ta-promoted catalysts is higher than that on other promoter metals, which leads to higher catalytic activity. This was due to the optimization of the acid to base ratio and the improved contact between the components of the catalyst. It is possible to deduce the relationship between the acidity-basicity characteristics and the metal-support interaction and it is important in the development of new nickel catalysts supported on zeolites. One of the latest methods for obtaining zeolites with the MFI structure that has gained attention is using clay-based material, destroying the skeleton, and reconstructing it. One of these materials is attapulgite, an adsorptive magnesium aluminum phyllosilicate. Liang et al. [117] used an attapulgite (ATP) clay to create an attapulgite-based zeolite (AZ) with a typical MFI zeolite structure. Then, they introduced Ni-Co alloys into the ATP-derived MFI zeolite (ADM). The Ni loading ratio to Co was 10:1. In a DRM reaction with a temperature of 700 °C and a TOS of 24 h, it showed considerable performance. The CH4 conversion of 78 %, and the CO2 conversion about 92 %. In a 100 h TOS test, the CH4 conversion had only decreased to 68 %, and the CO2 conversion was at 85 %. Further investigation into the results revealed that during the DRM process, electron transfer occurring at the interfaces of the Ni-Co alloy resulted in an enrichment of electrons at metallic Ni sites, thereby enhancing the capability to break CH bonds profoundly. The encapsulated structures provided a good interaction between the metal and support, ensuring that CHx* species generated on the metallic sites interact with CO2 molecules adsorbed on ADM zeolite, convert them into carbonates, and synthesize syngas through the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. In addition, oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface enhanced the adsorption of CO2 to form active oxygen species that can remove C* species for the complete dehydrogenation of methane. The 10Ni@ADM-y catalysts, where y indicates adding 0.05, 0.1, and 0.2 mol NaOH, respectively, during the synthesis procedure. The authors also mentioned that an ethylenediamine-assisted impregnation method was used to prepare the 10Ni1Co/ADM-0.1 catalyst by adopting ADM-0.1 zeolite as the support. Fig. 12 (a–c) shows the TEM images of all the spent catalysts. In contrast to the reduced 10Ni@ADM catalyst, after 24 h of stability examination, irregular dispersal of dark particles was observed, with a noticeable enlargement to 12.3 nm in grain size. This enlargement was due to the movement of nickel grain and partial of sintering caused by high temperature. Moreover, the observation of carbon nanotubes with ADM zeolite was confirmed, and these nanotubes were found to be coiled around the edge of the ADM zeolite with nickel metal grains sitting on them. On the other hand, the presence of NaOH in the 10Ni@ADM-0. 1 catalyst led to reduced CNTs formation while at the same time ensuring proper dispersion of the Ni metal particles and hindering the formation of large metallic Ni grains. These observations can relate to the formation of strong Ni-O-Si bonds and the reinforcing encapsulation effect; chemically and physically anchors the metallic nickel sites, preventing the Ni metal grains from sintering and being expelled. In the case of the 10Ni1Co@ADM-0.1 catalyst, neither metal fusion nor carbon nanotubes were detected on the edges or surface of the zeolite, indicating that the presence of cobalt species enhances the catalyst's resistance to sinter and limits the formation of carbon nanotubes. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 12 (c-1), the Ni-Co grain boundaries with lattice defects were still detected in the spent 10Ni1Co@ADM-0.1 catalyst, which confirms the high structure stability of 10Ni1Co@ ADM-0.1 catalyst during the long-term reaction. Also, Fig. 12(d), depicts that all spent catalysts presented a new peak at 26.2° that is attributed to the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface, and the peak intensity was found to decrease with the addition of NaOH and Co species. This indicates that NaOH and Co addition have a positive effect on restricting the formation of deposited carbon and promoting carbon elimination. The TG-DTG results presented in Fig. 12(e) indicate that no noticeable rise in catalyst weight was detected across all spent catalysts, suggesting that ADM zeolites' encapsulation effect can provide active sites with strong anti-oxidation capabilities, thus inhibiting catalyst deactivation caused by metal oxidation. However, a sharp decline in the weight of the catalyst was noticed in all the spent catalysts in the range of 400 °C to 700 °C due to the desorption of carbonaceous deposits from the catalyst surface. The catalyst weight loss results in descending order: 10Ni@ADM (45.9 %) > 10Ni1Co@ADM-0. 1 (32.2 %) > 10Ni@ADM-0. 1 (19.2 %), which confirms that the anti-coking ability of the 10Ni@ADM catalyst has been improved after the NaOH treatment and Co addition. It is also worth mentioning that the higher surface carbon deposition of the 10Ni1Co@ADM-0.1 catalysts than that of the 10Ni@ADM-0.1 catalysts can be attributed to the Ni-Co alloy interfaces with their high ability to cleave CH bonds and generate a great number of carbon sorts from methane dehydrogenation. 4.1.5 MOFs Porous coordination polymers known as MOFs are created by combining three key elements: a metal center, a pore volume and an organic ligand. Examples for this type of materials include the University of Oslo series (UiO), Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks (ZIFs), Materials of Institut Lavoisier (MILs), Porous Coordination Networks (PCNs) and Isoreticular Metal-Organic Frameworks (IRMOFs). Through the change of the link between the metal and organic ligands, researchers can obtain various MOF materials with different pore size, surface functional groups, and chemical properties [118]. Fig. 13 gives examples of various categories of MOFs. The recent discovery in the MOF research work was directed towards the preparation of new frameworks, as well as the modification of the frameworks by the incorporation of nanoparticles and the investigations into the catalytic activity of MOFs in several chemical reactions. The combination of MOF materials with nanotechnology has led to new opportunities for enhancing the efficiency of catalytic processes especially for energy purposes. For example, the incorporation of metal nanoparticles into MOFs may affect their catalytic performance by offering reaction sites and changing the electronic nature of the structure. Such enhancements are important for catalysis since MOFs are being explored for their capability to facilitate sustainable chemical transformations like methane reforming and carbon dioxide conversion. Vakili et al. [119] studied the influence of Pt nanoparticles on the UiO-67 MOF for Plasma-assisted DRM reaction. For synthesizing UiO-67 structure, they employed a microwave assisted technique and for Pt nanoparticles loading with 2 wt. %, they employed wetness impregnation method. The results found out that when this catalyst used in a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) reactor with the power of 11 W and feed flow rate of 100 ml.min-1 with the unity molar ratio of substrates, the conversions were about 55 % and 44 % for CH4 and CO2, respectively which when compared with UiO-67 as catalyst, represents slight improvement. They later with decreasing the feed flow rate to half, reached the 66 % conversion for CH4 and 51 % for CO2. The Pt@UiO-67 catalyst was stable in the plasma on-off cycling tests where conversion of CO2 and CH4 remained almost at the same level after four cycles. Further, SEM analysis revealed that its morphology and crystallinity were unchanged as was evidenced by XRD analysis. Moreover, the investigation of Pt nanoparticles by TEM showed that there was almost no sintering during the reaction. One limitation of the MOFs is their thermal instability.one way to solve that problem is using them as precursors to obtain more thermally stable materials like Al2O3, CeO2 and ZrO2. The two important parameters that should be considered is the metal centers in MOFs because they are main active site for catalytic reactions to be occurred on and the second is the linker material. Linkers play a crucial role in determining the stability and reusability of MOFs. They have the potential to affect the catalytic performance of MOFs by introducing intrinsic catalytic activity via functional groups [120]. To this regard, Karam et al. [121]. build a MOF derived Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. They synthesized MIL-53(Al) MOF and instead of using commercial benzene dicarboxylic acid (BDC) as an organic linker material, they used PET waste which consist of 85 wt. % of BDC. The result interpretation of DRM test with 13 h TOS in 650 °C (after reaching to 800 °C in an increasing trend) showed that catalyst synthesized using PET derived organic linker's performance was the same with commercial BDC linker concerning CH4 and CO2 conversion. Alli et al. [122] studied the influence of organic ligand on MOF-derived Ni- based catalyst in the DRM reaction. They juxtapose two ligands; benzene1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC) which also known as trimesic acid and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (BDC). The findings demonstrated that employing trimesic acid in the role of the organic ligand led to the creation of better performance and more stable catalysts. This was ascribed to smaller and more uniformly distributed particle sizes, which resulted from longer chain lengths and yielded a larger surface area. In terms of coke resistance, there was a negligible formation of coke with this approach. Concentrating on the tunable metal-support interaction, Shao et al. [123] proceed to make the MOF-derived Ni@ZrO2 catalyst by sacrificial Zr-MOFs template strategy. The Zr-based MOF synthesized through solvothermal method. They constructed three types of catalyst named A, B and C. In Ni/ZrO2-A catalyst, nickel was introduced directly into the hydrothermal reaction vessel along with the zirconium source. This implies that Ni and Zr are likely to interact during the formation process. In B type, Ni was introduced into Zr-based MOF. This indicates that Ni is incorporated into the MOF structure, potentially forming Ni-Zr bonds within the framework. In Ni/ZrO2 C catalyst, Ni was introduced into the already formed ZrO2 product. This designates that Ni is added onto the surface or into the structure of pre-formed ZrO2, without direct interaction during the formation process. With putting these catalysts through a 5 h DRM test in 750 °C, Ni/ZrO2-B found out to be the superior catalyst with CH4 conversion of 78 % and CO2 conversion about 70 %. The H2/CO ratio was also close to 0.85. The XRD analyses revealed that the ZrO2 matrices comprised of mixed crystalline phases; monoclinic and tetragonal ZrO2 which influenced the presence of surface oxygen vacancies and acid sites. This study also revealed that, smaller Ni particles favored activation of CH4, while the acid sites favored activation of CO2, and the oxygen vacancies slowed down carbon deposition. The high catalytic activity of Ni/ZrO2-B can be described by the high spreading of Ni nanoparticles and the strong interaction among the metal and the support. The interaction assists in keeping Ni distributed evenly throughout the catalyst thereby enhancing the stability of the catalyst in the long run. Zhou et al. [124] prepared Ni/CeO2 with MOF derived CeO2 for low-temperature (400 °C to 600 °C) DRM. At 550 °C, Ni/CeO2-M (MOF-derived) achieves notably higher CO2 and CH4 conversions (40.1 % and 30.8 %, respectively) compared to Ni/CeO2 C (commercial CeO2) which was 27.3 % and 15.5 %, respectively. Following a 10 h DRM reaction, Ni/CeO2-M displays superior resistance to carbon deposition and sintering compared to Ni/CeO2 C. Morphological analysis showed uniform immobilization of metallic Ni on Ni/CeO2-M, contrasting with the Ni accumulation observed on Ni/CeO2 C. As mentioned above, the highly dispersed metallic Ni0 on Ni/CeO2-M aids in CH4 dissociation, while increased oxygen vacancies aid in CO2 dissociation into CO and active O. 4.1.6 MXenes MXenes are a type of two-dimensional compounds consisting of transition metal carbonitrides, and nitrides and carbides generally represented by the formula of Mn+1 XnTx (n = 1–3). In this formula, M denotes an early transition metal (e.g., Sc, Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, Ta, Cr, and Mo), X represents carbon and/or nitrogen, and Tx signifies various surface terminations such as hydroxyl, oxygen, or fluorine [125]. Since its discovery in 2011, this material has quickly piqued the interest of research groups all over the world in a variety of fields, from energy storage [126], catalysis [127] and water treatment [128] to sensors [129] and even wearable electronics [130]. Given the multifunctional nature of MXenes, it is clear that they hold significant potential in various applications. In this section, we will specifically focus on the catalytic applications of MXenes in DRM reaction. The usage of Mxenes for catalytic purposes is an emerging trend. Huang et al. [131] used Ni catalysts supported on multilayer vanadium carbide MXene (m-V2C) with different V2O3 amounts for DRM. With the ideal Ni loading of 13 wt. %, under a 800 °C temperature and 9 h TOS, they achieved 91 % and 85 % conversion for CO2 and CH4, respectively.
