The aforementioned catalyst showed a good stability during a 90 h test also due to the strong metal-support interaction. In situ DRIFTS examination, revealed some facts about mechanism of the reaction. It showed that methane undergoes activation on the Ni particles, leading to the production of CHx and H on the 13Ni/m-V2O3-V2C surface during a DRM reaction. Meanwhile, CO2 interacts with m-V2O3-V2C to create carbonates within the catalyst. These carbonate entities then react with the byproducts of methane pyrolysis, swiftly forming formate species, which subsequently decompose into CO. The mechanism looks credible because the CO2 molecules absorbed onto the support have the ability to swiftly migrate and readily engage with the dissociation byproducts of CH4 on the Ni surface. Wysocka et al. [132] examined the effect of preparation method on the morphology and catalytic performance with the DRM reaction of Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC catalysts. They synthesized various nickel-modified catalysts using different methods. Firstly, the catalyst labeled as Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC-U was prepared by adding a mixture of MXene and nickel ions to deionized water, followed by the dropwise addition of a urea solution. The suspension was then warmed up at 120 °C with the time of 4 h in a Teflon autoclave. After cooling, the catalyst was washed and dried. Secondly, the catalyst labeled as Ni-V2CTx/V2AlCOH was synthesized by regulating the pH of a suspension of MXene and nickel ions to 11 using sodium hydroxide solution, followed by a hydrothermal reaction at 180 °C for 16 h. Likewise, after the washing process and drying, the catalyst was collected. The Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC-UOH catalyst was synthesized using a simultaneous method of mixing MXene with nickel nitrate and then adding the urea solution and adjusting the pH to 11 and subjected to hydrothermal reaction. Finally, the Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC-IMP catalyst was prepared by the impregnation of MXene in the nickel ions, washing, and drying process. All the catalysts synthesized were dried at 500 °C under vacuum for 24 h. All the methods led to the modification of the catalyst by the incorporation of nickel species which made it suitable for the next reactions. For evaluating catalytic activity, synthesized catalysts were employed in a DRM reaction in 800 °C temperature and 20 h TOS. Their achieved results are shown in the Fig. 14 . The catalytic performance of the catalysts was evaluated as following order: Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC-IMP > Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC-U > Ni-V2CTx/V2AlCOH > Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC-UOH, based on substrate conversions and the H2/CO ratio observed in the exit stream. The improved catalytic performance of Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC-IMP arises from the even dispersion of nickel across the accordion-like surface of V2CTx/V2AlC. This distribution was verified through XPS analysis, which indicated that positively charged nickel ions bond with fluorine atoms on the multi-layered V2CTx surface. The authors deduced that throughout the catalytic process, nickel particles serve as active centers for methane decomposition and hydrogen generation. The multi-layered vanadium carbide acts as a pivotal point for both CH4 and CO2 activation. Nevertheless, the activation of CO2 and subsequent CO formation predominates over oxidation and carburization cycles. The Ni-V2CTx/V2AlC-IMP as the superior catalyst suffers from high carbon deposition content (72 wt. %) which in this entry Ni-V2CTx/V2AlCOH had a better performance (only 2.2wt. %). Tahkur et al. [133] explored the application of V2CTx in tandem with an oxy-carbide (V2O3-V8C7) as a catalyst for DRM, devoid of an active metal component. The oxy-carbide was formed in situ, serving to safeguard against the full oxidation of MXene and the subsequent decline in catalytic efficiency. This observation also implies that MXene functions as a redox catalyst through cycles of oxidation and carburization. They proved that the m-V2CTx functions as both a precursor and support for V2O3-V8C7 nanocrystals. To sum up, potential of MXenes as a catalyst in the DRM process has been identified, and the effects of the method of catalyst preparation and the composition of materials have been determined. The main features contributing to a high level of CO2 and CH4 conversion are a strong interaction between the metals and MXene supports and the opportunity to use MXenes as both a catalyst and a support. However, there is a fine line between getting very high catalytic activity and at the same time avoiding formation of undesirable byproducts such as carbon deposition. Design of an MXene-based catalysts with high efficiency and stability, along with ability to control carbon formation is crucial for the progress of MXene's application in DRM reaction and has a long way to go. 4.1.7 Alumina (Al2O3) Alumina, or aluminum oxide (Al2O3), is a diverse material that is commonly used in catalysis because of its desirable characteristics. Alumina is an excellent catalyst support material because of its properties mentioned above; however, it also has some drawbacks [134–136]. This is why it is crucial to evaluate the potential benefits and possible limitations of using this catalyst for different catalytic processes, such as the DRM reaction. These types of supporting materials offers some advantages like high surface area, thermal stability, chemical inertness (which inhabit support involvedness in side reactions and ensuring catalyst stability), tailorable surface chemistry (modifiable surface with techniques such as impregnation, doping, functionalization, etc.) and more importantly Cost-effectiveness [137–140]. Among catalytic systems investigated for the DRM process, those featuring alumina-supported catalysts with nickel as the metallic phase have garnered probably the utmost attention within published papers. Such support systems exhibit unparalleled superiority over their counterparts. As a confirmations, literature suggests the activity of supported Ni-based catalysts decreases in the following order: Al2O3 > MgO > SiO2 >ZrO2 > TiO2 [141]. γ-Al2O3 has the highest surface area among different forms of alumina so it is not surprising that it has been investigated as a supporting material for nickel-based catalysts in the DRM reaction. The catalytic activity of nickel nanoparticles depends much on the oxide supports, which are important in controlling the DRM reactivity. For instance, γ-Al2O3 has an acidic property that promotes methane decomposition hence increasing DRM activity. However, Ni catalysts supported on alumina still suffer from severe carbon deposition due to the methane decomposition and CO disproportionation [142,143]. In order to decrease this coking tendency, the following approaches have been proposed; it is possible to control the size of Ni particles using specific precursors or the support's basicity could be enhanced by the addition of alkali or alkaline rare earth (La, Ce, Sm) oxides. Since CO2 is the only weak oxidation agent in the DRM reaction system, the key point to the elimination of coke on the catalyst surface is to enhance the gasification of coke by CO2 [144]. The existence of strong Lewis basicity enhances the catalyst's capability to chemisorb CO2. The presence of chemisorbed CO2 molecules can aid in oxidizing the carbon deposited on the catalyst surface [145]. Furthermore, promoters can effectively impede the phase transformation of γ-Al2O3 to low-surface-area α-Al2O3 during the reaction process [146]. Moreover, gaining insights into the intrinsic activity and coke resistance of specific active sites in Ni/γ-Al2O3 is pivotal for the development of superior catalyst designs. During the calcination process Ni would dissolve into the γ-Al2O3 support and create a nonstoichiometric spinel structure. Later on, during the reduction process, a part of Ni would precipitate out of the spinel lattice. Thus, in the reduced Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, three type of Ni species that include Ni in the spinel, bounded Ni exsoluted from the spinel and free Ni on the surface of γ-Al2O3 may exist. These different Ni species have different metal-support interactions (MSIs) that affect the performance of the catalyst in the DRM. There are some reports that tetra-coordinated Ni in the NiAl2O4 spinel structure is the active site for DRM and, metal Ni particles are less active but cause a limited coking of the catalysts [147,148]. Naidu et al. [149] studied the coke formation on Ni based catalyst supported with Al2O3 and MgO- Al2O3 with Ce and La as promoters in DRM. The findings revealed that Unpromoted catalysts especially 5 % Ni supported over γ-Al2O3 and 30 % MgO in MgO-Al2O3 exhibited higher catalytic performance and coke resistance due to MSI and stable MgAl2O4 spinel formation that hinder coke formation on Ni particles. Among the promoted catalysts, 5Ni1Ce0.5La/30MgO.70Al2O3 displayed the highest coke resistance due to lower coke deposition in amorphous form and favorable textural properties. Al-fatesh et al. [150] developed an Iron-promoted zirconia-alumina supported Ni catalyst for the DRM usage in condition of 800 °C and 7 h TOS with volumetric feed ratio of CH4: CO2: N2 = 3:3:1 and GHSV = 42,000 mL/(min.gcat). Adding iron as a promoter to the nickel-based catalyst has proven to leading to forming reducible iron species alongside with reducible NiO species, increase basicity, and promote the deposition of oxidizable carbon. By Adding just 1 % by weight of Fe to a 5 %Ni/10 %ZrO290 %Al2O3 catalyst, a higher interaction with CO2 was observed, along with the formation of reducible NiO species that strongly interact with the support, leading to an approximately 80 % hydrogen (H₂) yield. When the Fe content was increased to 2 wt. %, extra iron oxide compounds that can undergo reduction were formed, resulting in a noticeable increase in H₂ yield to 84 %. Despite significant weight loss in the Fe-promoted catalysts the high H2 yield was sustained because the rate of methane breakdown was balanced by the diffusion of carbon deposits. Lastly, the results showed adding 3wt. % Fe into the 5 %Ni/10 %ZrO290 %Al2O3 catalyst, the highest level of interaction with CO2, a wide variety of reducible NiO species, low formation of graphitic carbon and 87 % H2 yield was achieved. These improvements in the catalytic characteristics of a nickel-based catalyst suggest that the addition of iron can increase the generation of H2 as well as the stability of the catalyst. Cao et al. [144] used K2CO3 as a promoter of Ni catalyst supported on Alumina as a dynamic coke remover in DRM. This work demonstrates that when 1 wt. % K2CO3 is used as a promoter in the Ni–Al2O3 catalyst, this results in improved long-term stability owing to improved interaction between Ni and Al2O3 and reduced nickel particle sintering. This results in more stable catalytic performance(87 % conversion for methane and 97 % for carbon dioxide after 96 h time on stream was achieved) with less coke formation after use (with rate of approximately 75 % less than conventional Ni/Al₂O₃). Additionally, K₂CO₃ increases the number of alkaline sites on the catalysts, promoting carbon dioxide adsorption and enhancing in-situ consumption of disordered carbon through the KECR process, which improves resistance to coke buildup (showed in Fig. 15 ). The study concludes that K2CO3 is an effective additive to enhance the performance and durability of nickel-based catalysts in the dry reforming of methane. Because of vast quantity of tuning Ni-based catalyst on alumina is with the help of promoters, a summary of published articles on this pathway can be found in Table 5 . Pirshahid et al. [151] developed a new Ni-based mesoporous alumina-silica supported catalyst for DRM reaction. With varying nickel content from 5 to 15 %, they observed increased catalyst efficiency with nickel loading enhancement, with 15 wt. % Ni exhibiting the best activity (XCO2 = 79 %, XCH4 = 74.5 %) and stability (activity drop for CH4 ≈ 2.7 % and CO2 ≈ 0.3 %) at 700 °C for 5h Operational conditions such as GHSV and CH4/CO2 ratio affected conversions, with higher GHSV leading to decreased conversions. Variation in calcination and reduction temperatures did not significantly impact the results. Catalyst surface is very sensitive since the start of a catalytic reaction depends on the surface atoms of the catalyst and the reactant molecules. Kim et al. [152] prepared a Ni-Al2O3 catalyst for DRM through the spray-pyrolysis-assisted evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method. Their objective was to understand how composition segregation regulates alterations in the catalyst's surface. As a result of this the catalyst was submitted to H2 pretreatment to cause composition segregation. This process led to the effective separation of Ni nanoparticles into different areas of the catalyst particles during post-annealing as well as its reduction to the metal. The particle size of the Ni nanoparticles on the catalyst surface depended on the post-annealing temperature, but the electronic properties did not follow this trend. Higher reduction temperature resulted in particle sintering rather than metal segregation hence a drop in the number of active sites. Sintering was observed to affect the efficiency of the catalyst in DRM where the initial conversion of CH4/CO2 correlated to the Ni surface density. Furthermore, the catalysts with lower oxygen vacancy density were found to be more sensitive to the deactivation where carbon deposition was observed on the surface of the catalyst after the reaction. In another novel synthesis method strategy, Wang et al. [153] developed a rapid, efficient and solvent-free method for producing mesoporous aluminum-based catalysts through a one-step reactive cyclic extrusion process. Ni/Al2O3 samples which prepared by this method, demonstrated superior and durable catalytic activity for 100 h at 750 °C as shown in Fig. 16 . NiAl2Ox species refer to compounds formed during the synthesis process. The XRD patterns indicate that Ni species may be dispersed uniformly or incorporated into the sublattice of γ-Al2O3. TEM images and EDS-mapping results further demonstrate a highly uniform distribution of Ni species within the NiAl2Ox samples. Additionally, with increasing nickel loadings, diffraction peaks associated with NiO can be observed in the NiAl2Ox samples, suggesting that higher nickel content leads to the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel phases. Al2O3/Ni/Al2O3 sandwich like catalyst was another catalyst structure created by Zhao et al. [154] which exhibited extraordinary stability and activity. In a 400 h usage of this catalyst under a condition of 800 °C temperature and GHSV equal to 300 L.gNi -1.h-1, the CH4 conversion was nearly stable on 92.5 % while CO2 was around 94 %. These results suggest that this catalyst has potential for industrial applications. The high stability could be primarily attributed to the double interactions of Ni with the γ-Al2O₃support and the alumina film, which effectively inhibit nickel agglomeration at high temperatures and reduce the risk of carbon deposition. Zhang et al. [155] in order to develop a coking resistant and stable catalytic system for DRM, used Nanosheet-assembled Al2O3 (NA-Al2O3) with hierarchical hollow microspheres to support Ni nano particles. The result for this catalyst being used in DRM reaction at 800 °C under a high GHSV of 216 000 mL/(gcat·h) and at a high concentration of CH4/CO2/N2 of 4.5/4.5/1 and 250 h time range, were respectable (95.3 % and 98.7 % for CH4 and CO2 respectively). A 60 h activation period is necessary for the Ni/(NA-Al2O3) catalyst, during which the active nickel species are slowly released from the NiAl2O₄ spinel in the Ni/(NA-Al2O3) catalyst, allowing them to diffuse and group together to form stable nickel nanoparticles with a size of 18.0 nm. This process is influenced by the spatial constraints of the hierarchical hollow microsphere structure of the NA-Al2O3 support. The spherical nickel nanoparticles, formed by the exsolution of active nickel from the NiAl2O₄spinel and the spatial confinement within the NA-Al2O3 support, exhibit enhanced CO₂ adsorption and a greater number of surface hydroxyl groups. These factors contribute to the catalyst's long-term stability and superior resistance to coking in the DRM reaction. The relationship between alumina's morphology and the performance of nickel-based catalysts supported on alumina was demonstrated by Shen et al. [141]. They found that among the different alumina structures, nanosheet, nanofiber and particle which they coded as S, F and P, respectively, the Ni-Al2O3 -S catalyst showed the uppermost activity nevertheless, as far as the stability aspect is concerned the Ni-Al2O3 -F catalyst exhibited a better performance compared to the other catalysts. Li et al. [168] studied nickel catalysts supported on alumina with three distinct morphologies, flower-like (Al2O3-F), wire-like (Al2O3-W), and sphere-like (Al2O3-S),were prepared to study their performance in the DRM with the condition of 700 °C temperature and 20 h TOS. These catalysts had different levels of activity and coking resistance for the reactions they catalyzed. In particular, the Ni-Al2O3 -W had the highest catalytic performance (72 % for CH4 and 86 % for CO2 conversion) and coking resistance owing to strong metal-support interaction, well dispersed small nickel nanoparticles and strong activation ability for CO2. Ni/Al2O3-F also revealed a high coking resistance resulting from a high tendency of activating CO2. However, the encapsulating effect of the Al2O3-F structure cause the active nickel sites on the catalyst surface to decrease, and as a result lower initial catalytic activity was observed. On the other hand, Ni/Al2O3-S demonstrated weaker CO2 activation and larger nickel particles and as a result, significant formation of filamentous carbon was observed after long-term DRM tests. XRD and in situ DRIFT studies revealed that the hydroxyl groups (OH*) in these catalysts functioned as coke precursor traps and reacted with the CHx* species derived from methane cracking, which are the principal factors that determine the anti-coke performance of these catalysts. Huang et al. [169] demonstrated that the core–shell structure Ni@Al2O3 synthesized using the inverse micro-emulsion technique compared with conventional Ni/Al2O3 made by the impregnation method, had superiority in either activity or stability. Gholizadeh et al. [170] investigated the cubic ordered mesoporous alumina (COMA) structure on Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Result showed that Ni loading of 15 wt. % has the best performance for the DRM reaction in terms of reactants conversion. After putting the 15 %NiO/COMA in a 210 h stability test in 700 °C, GHSV=18,000 mL/(g.h), it showed 93 % and 80 % conversions for CH4 and CO2 respectively. The results of TGA&DSC analysis demonstrated that carbonaceous kinds deposited in the quantity of 5 wt. % on the structure of 15 %NiO/COMA catalyst during 210 h of DRM reaction. Zhang et al. [171] proposed another way to improvement the catalytic activity of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst by changing the structure of alumina. The major issue with the conventional Ni-Al2O3 catalysts is that there is a strong metal-support interaction resulting due to the presence of excess hydroxyl groups on the alumina support which results in the poor utilization of nickel and restricts its use in various industries. The preparation of specific defect sites on alumina can pin active Ni sites and enhance catalytic performance in the DRM reaction. According to the previous reports surface oxygen vacancies of Al2O3 are said to be related with the elimination of hydroxyl groups [172,173]. In view of this, they employed an acid etching process to eliminate hydroxyl groups on the γ-Al2O3 surface leaving behind vacancy defects which were responsible for anchoring of active nickel sites. This approach creates reasonable interaction with the alumina support and at the same time increases the adsorption and activation of CO2 to give a superior activation of CH4. This strategy proved to be superior to the conventional Ni-Al2O3 catalysts in the sense that it provided a more efficient route to DRM. The influence of calcination temperature as one of the preparation steps of Ni/mesoporous-Al2O3 was studied by Bian et al. [174]. The catalysts were prepared using an incipient wetness impregnation method and subsequently calcined at various temperatures, ranging from 500 to 800 °C. When compared to nickel catalysts supported on commercial alumina, these catalysts exhibited notably higher conversion rates and reduced carbon deposition during the DRM. Such a behavior, in accordance with the TPR results, can be attributed to the fact that the Ni/M-Al2O3 catalysts contain only NiO-Al2O3 and NiAl2O4 species, whereas no free NiO species are detected. Among these catalysts, the Ni/M-Al2O3–700 variant revealed the best performance, achieving 77.6 % methane conversion and 85.4 % carbon dioxide conversion at 700 °C. TGA and SEM results indicated that carbon deposition after 20 h of DRM testing was minimal, accounting for only 3.8wt. %, primarily in the form of amorphous carbon. Bian et al.’s work further reinforces the critical role of spinel species and underscores their importance in enhancing the performance of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts in DRM reaction. Zhou et al. [175] explored this subject more precisely. They assume that when the final calcination temperature is increased to 900 °C, resulting in the exclusive formation of NiAl2O4, a catalyst with strong metal-support interactions is achieved. For the long-term DRM reaction that lasted approximately 100 h at 700 °C and with an equal ratio of CH4/CO2, the reduced Ni from NiAl2O4 exhibited good stability against sintering and coking. The probable reason is that the process of reduction of NiAl2O4 is not fully complete leaving behind Ni sites that has a high affinity with the alumina support. This strong interaction is believed to play an important role in stabilizing Ni during DRM and improving its stability against deactivation processes such as coking. Qiu et al. [176] in a more recently published article, concluded the same results as the antecedents. From the H2-TPR results, they discovered that when certain parameters in the catalyst preparation and reaction processes are optimized, the amount of Ni reduced from the NiAl2O4 spinel which is highly resistant to cocking is boosted. This results in a decrease of inert carbon deposition on the catalyst surfaces in both filament and graphite form, which is very essential for Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. NiAl2O4 spinel content in the catalyst is quite sensitive to calcination temperature, and calcination rate additionally controls its content and reduction characteristics. In their study, the best conditions were determined to be the calcination rate of 5 °C/min, the calcination temperature of 600 °C and the reduction temperature of 700 °C. These conditions offer the best trade-off for attaining high nickel reduction with little or no formation of carbon. The Ni catalyst supported on bimodal alumina with both mesoporous and macroporous structures (Ni/MM-A) was created by Ma et al. [177] using the evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) technique and the incipient wetness impregnation method. To generate the macroporous structure, polystyrene latex spheres with a diameter of 100 nm were employed as a sacrificial template. By implementing this catalyst in a DRM reaction with the condition of 700 °C temperature and CH4/CO2 = 1 with 100 h TOS, it was perceived that this catalyst possess both good activity (75 % conversion for CH4 and 85 % for CO2) and good stability toward formation of graphitic carbon. This was due to the bimodal structure, which facilitated mass transport and improved resistance to stubborn graphitic carbon build-up. Owgi et al. [178] created a new fibrous silica-alumina structure by hydrothermal method in order to be used as a support for Ni nanocrystals. This catalyst in a 10 h DRM test in the condition of 850 °C and GHSV = 50,000 mL/(g.h) with the feed ratio of CH4/CO2 = 1, achieved CH4 conversion of 97.5 %. Compare to this, the Co supported with the same supporting material did poorly on the test and only could reach 20.63 % conversion for CH4. The excellent behavior for Ni catalyst is attributed to its large surface area (338.56 m²/g), fine dispersion of nickel particles, and strong metal-support interactions. The catalyst's strong resistance to sintering, achieved by limiting the movement of nickel atoms or crystallites on the support, also contributes to its high stability while the large size of the Co supported crystals is the one to blame for its poor stability performance. The noteworthy point here is that Co/Al2O3 catalysts in DRM are not always have poor performance. For instance, Ruckenstein et al. [179] with a 9 %Co/Al2O3 made by impregnation method, were being able to reach high conversions(more than 90 %) in a DRM reaction(900 °C, GHSV = 60,000 mL/(g.h) and CH4/CO2 = 1) for both reactants. In another work, Khairudin et al. [180] by using a 10 %Co/Al2O3 catalyst, calcined at 500 °C and reduced under hydrogen at 900 °C, in a DRM reaction at 850 °C with a CH₄/CO₂ ratio of 1:1 and a GHSV of 6 L.g-1.h-1, yielded remarkable catalytic activity and sustained performance during long-term operation. This setup achieved excellent conversions of CO2 (96 %) and CH4 (98 %), along with high yields of H2 (83 %) and CO (91 %), with minimal carbon deposition (3 wt. %) after 100 h of continuous reaction. In a more recent established study, Shah et al. [181] developed a bimetallic catalyst (Co-Mox/TiO2-Al2O3) in which MOx = La,Ce, Mg and K, for using in DRM reaction. Titania-alumina composite oxide supports were synthesized using a template-assisted solvothermal technique, followed by the co-impregnation of cobalt and also various promoters onto the freshly prepared support material. The DRM reaction conditions were as follows: 750 °C, GHSV=60,000 mL.g-1.h-1. In a 20 h TOS the catalytic activity, based on the conversion values of the reactants, was as follows: Mg-promoted > Ce-promoted > La- promoted > K-promoted.since the Mg-promoted catalyst demonstrated the best performance, it was chosen for the 60 h test, during which it was maintained about 93 % conversion for the CH4 and 95 % for the CO2 during the whole time. The GHSV in the long-term test was lower than in the 20 h test (40,000 mL.g-1.h-1). The possible explanation for this hierarchy based on the CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD is that catalysts with potassium as a promoter exhibited the greatest number of basic sites, while those promoted with La had the most acidic sites. The addition of La enhanced the distribution of cobalt, whereas Mg promotion strengthened the metal-support interaction. However, La-promoted catalysts experienced deactivation due to the oxidation of the active metal and the formation of hard carbon. In search of the optimum Ni loading in Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, Choya et al. [182] applied a catalyst for the DRM, which was a series of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared from sub-stoichiometric NiAl2O4 precursors. The Ni/Al molar ratio in these precursors ranged between 0.5 and 0.05. These catalysts were examined for their effectiveness in the dry reforming of methane, focusing on how different ratios of nickel and aluminum impact their performance. The NiAl2O4-based catalysts, particularly those with a Ni/Al molar ratio between 0.15 and 0.25, demonstrated significant performance at a GHSV of 90,000 h-1 and a temperature of 650 °C. The most effective catalyst (14 wt. % Ni), which achieved 93 % CH4 conversion and 80 % CO2 conversion, could maintain operation for 200 h despite the considerable formation of carbon nanotubes (approximately 1 gC/gcat). To recapitulate the techniques applied in order to improve the reaction activity and coke tolerance of the alumina-supported catalysts with metallic content that is mostly nickel, the illustration showing these routes is presented in Fig. 17 . This depicted display showcases how differently, the methods are employed to boost catalyst performance and to minimize coke buildup. These measures mostly consist of varying the catalyst type, the structure of support, and the reaction between the metal and the support. Approaches include: • Promoter Addition: adding hetro atoms like Mg, K, La and Ce seems to have positive effect on the performance of the catalyst as described above. • Metal Loading and Distribution: The qualitative and spatial variation of fibrous metallic phases, adequate distribution and the refinement of the size of the particles have all been key factors in elevating the performance of the catalyst. • Support Morphology: Creating structures with certain characteristics, such as high surface area, porosity, or unique shapes, can improve catalyst performance and reduce coke buildup on the catalyst surface. • Reduction and Calcination Conditions: Optimizing the tempering and sorption stages for the avoidance of formation of the metal phases and thereby the coking. • Oxygen Vacancies: Oxygen-deficient support matrix with the purpose of enhancing the catalyst reactivity, improving the gas diffusion and creating the active site formation that can be beneficial in the formation of coke resistant material and hence, contributes to increased coke tolerance. Creating this illustration in Fig. 17, integrating all strategies, makes it easier to display different options to raise the activity of the alumina-supported catalysts and the endurance to carbon in form of coke in DRM reaction. 4.1.7.1 Mechanistic insights into alkali metal promotion The establishment of fundamental knowledge regarding how K and Na alkali metal promoters affect the nature of active phases in DRM catalysts seems essential for developing optimized catalyst designs. Several important mechanisms enable alkali metals to modify Ni-based catalysts. The donation of electrons from K and Na alkali metals to Ni active sites results in modifications to their electronic nature. XPS studies demonstrate that Ni 2p3/2 binding energies decrease in K/Na-promoted catalysts compared to Ni/Al2O3 without promoters [183] which verifies electronic promotion. Alkali metals donate electrons to nickel which shifts the d-band center of Ni while weakening Ni-C bonds thus preventing carbon nucleation and growth. The electronic modification simultaneously helps improve CO2 activation through enhanced electron back-donation to the CO2 π* orbital which facilitates CO2 dissociation to CO and active oxygen species. The K and Na promoters create significant modifications to the Ni/Al2O3 metal-support interface. The analysis of Ni particles through in-situ FTIR and DRIFTS methods shows that alkali metals generate specific active site arrangements at Ni particle edges [184]. The active site ensembles facilitate the interaction of CH4 activation carbon species with CO2 dissociation oxygen species. The optimal concentration range of 0.5–2 wt % K/Na promotes the maximum number of active sites at the interface without impeding Ni's fundamental active sites. The support binds Ni nanoparticles to its surface through strong metal-promoter-support interactions which K2CO3 establishes in addition to its KCER mechanism. STEM-EDX mapping reveals that alkali metals position themselves at Ni-support contacts to stop Ni particle movement and prevent Ni particle coalescence during DRM reactions at high temperatures. The stabilization mechanism allows Ni particles to stay small (5–10 nm) instead of growing to 15–20 nm while achieving better metal dispersion in the reaction period [185,186]. The promotion efficiency between K and Na differs although both elements enhance catalyst performance. Catalysts promoted by K demonstrate better coke resistance than Na-promoted systems because K exhibits stronger basicity and enhanced mobility during reaction conditions [187]. The KECR(K‐Enhanced) mechanism operates more strongly during K-promoted conditions yet Na mainly acts through electronic modification and structural stabilization. Na-promoted catalysts show better initial activity because Na covers Ni sites less than K promotion. The selection between potassium and sodium promoters as catalyst promoters depends on the reaction parameters and required catalyst operational life. Support properties strongly modify the joint working behavior between K and Na promotional agents. Alkali metals on γ-Al2O3 surface react with hydroxyl groups to generate new basic sites which enhance CO2 adsorption capability. The strong metal-support interaction between Ni and alumina undergoes modification by K and Na which stops the formation of inactive NiAl2O4 spinel phases during high-temperature operation [188]. The preservation of Ni0 active species through support properties results in sustained catalytic activity during prolonged reaction times. 4.1.8 Ceria (CeO2) Ceria is a suitable support material for catalysis since it provides rich oxygen vacancies and favorable redox characteristics, thus favoring the generation of atomically dispersed catalysts (M/CeO2) because of strong MSI interactions [189]. However, the bulk CeO2 powder exhibits the problem of thermal instability whereby the structure decomposes at higher temperatures, thus enhancing a reduction in surface area and activity. Nevertheless, due to ceria's redox properties and its high capacity to retain oxygen, it can release and restore oxygen during oxidation and reduction processes (Ce4+ ⇆ Ce3+), thus minimizing the chances of carbon formation during methane reformation. Investigations of CeO2 performance modification have mainly involved the adjustment of the crystallite size, size distribution, and morphology in a bid to increase the catalytic activity [190,191]. Well-aligned mesoporous cerium oxide (mp-CeO2) shows enhanced thermal stability compared to bulk CeO2 due to the large surface area, three-dimensional interconnected channel network, and ordered mesoporous character. These mp-CeO2 nanomaterials can be synthesized by hydrothermal synthesis, microwave synthesis and hard template synthesis using KIT-6 and SBA-15 and so on. regarding this, Li et al. [190] synthesized ordered mesoporous ceria (mp-CeO2) using SBA-15 as template to confine Ni single atoms for DRM at 750 °C. The 2.1 wt. % Ni @ mp-CeO2 catalyst was characterised by a high density of oxygen vacancies and basic sites which enhance the activation of CO2 and generation of reactive oxygen to reduce C deposition compared to the Ni/CeO2 catalyst prepared through impregnation used as reference. The mechanistic advantage lies in the strong metal-ceria interface that promotes CO2 activation through the formation of carbonate intermediates (CO3 ²⁻), which subsequently react with surface carbon species to generate CO, completing the carbon removal cycle. It also inhibited the Ni cluster sintering, which was beneficial for the catalyst stability and the mesoporous structure contributed to the improvement of the pore structure. The Ni@mp-CeO2 catalyst showed a higher CH4 conversion rate and a lower deactivation rate than the Ni/CeO2 catalyst. These catalysts were able to convert 93 % of methane within 40 h TOS and experienced a decrease of only 8 % in a 120 h stability test. Ceria with various morphologies, such as dumbbell (CeO2-D), bouquet (CeO2-B), and shuttle (CeO2-S) shapes (Fig. 18 ), were hydrothermally synthesized by Gao et al. [192] to examine the impact of ceria shape on the catalytic performance of 10 %Ni/CeO2 in a DRM reaction under condition of 800 °C, GHSV = 21,600 mL.h-1.gcat -1, CH4/CO2 = 1 and 6 h TOS. The findings revealed that Ni/CeO2-D achieved the highest reaction conversions, with CH4 and CO2 conversions reaching 92 % and 87 %, respectively, and the highest TOF. This morphology-dependent performance is attributed to the superior exposure of specific crystal facets in the dumbbell shape, particularly the (100) and (110) facets, which exhibit higher surface energy and oxygen mobility compared to the more stable (111) facets predominant in other morphologies. Characterization techniques (XPS, H2-TPR, and Raman) confirmed that Ni/CeO2-D possessed plentiful oxygen vacancies and robust metal-support interactions, enhancing the activity of CH4 and CO2 and leading to its superior catalytic performance. Results acquired from XRD, TGA and raman spectroscopy designated that The weight loss for the spent catalysts increased in the following order: Ni/CeO2-D < Ni/CeO2-S < Ni/CeO2-B < Ni/CeO2 C. This specifies that Ni/CeO2-D exhibited the least amount of carbon deposition. Recently, Vasiliades et al. [193] investigated the influence of nano-CeO2 morphology on DRM over Ni/CeO2, using transient and isotopic methods. Comparing the results obtained for nanorods (NR) and nanopolyhedra (NP) forms of CeO2, the study provided valuable information on the effect of the shape of CeO2 on the important kinetic characteristics of the materials, including activation energy barriers for the surface oxygen reduction, bulk oxygen diffusion, and carbon oxidation. The authors demonstrated that CeO2 nanorods with their exposed (110) and (100) facets possess higher Ce3+ ion and oxygen vacancy densities than the (111) facets found in nanopolyhedra which leads to dissimilar reaction mechanisms and thermodynamic properties. The Ni/CeO2 NR catalyst was found to perform significantly better than Ni/CeO2 NP in terms of these steps, which had significantly lower activation energies for these steps. The improved performance of Ni/CeO2 NR was due to increased oxygen mobility, higher reducibility, and higher concentration of oxygen vacancies that lead to higher rates of carbon gasification and reduce the accumulation of carbon by 30 %. Isotopic studies with ¹⁸O labeled CO2 revealed that lattice oxygen participates directly in the oxidation of surface carbon species through an oxygen exchange mechanism, with the rate of this exchange being substantially faster on nanorod morphologies. As demonstrated before by other works, these findings emphasize the essential role of CeO2 morphology in optimizing DRM catalysts. Research shows that Ni-based catalysts suffer from significant coke formation, especially at low temperatures (below 600 °C) [194–196]. To address this issue, and to enhance coke resistance and thermal stability, noble metals such as Pt, Pd, Rh, and Ru have been investigated as active sites. Among these, Ru is the most cost-effective and is considered a promising candidate for the DRM reaction. In this regard, Zhou et al. [197] conducted an efficient and stable low-temperature DRM reaction using a Ru/CeO2 catalyst. They performed a comparative study between Ni/CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 in low-temperature DRM. They synthesized Ni/CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 by one-pot microwave-assisted hydrothermal method and green precursors (Urea and glucose). Additionally, they investigated the effects of different Ru loadings on the Ru/CeO2 catalyst by preparing catalysts with Ru to Ce ratios of 1:5, 1:20 and 1:100, named Ru/5CeO2, Ru/20CeO2 and Ru/100CeO2, respectively. The DRM reaction was performed in a fixed bed reactor. Ru/20CeO2 and Ni/CeO2 catalysts were tested at 600 °C for 18 h to assess their performance. The two catalysts exhibited comparable conversion of CH4 and CO2, with the H2/CO ratio of 0.88 (58 % of CH4 and 73 % of CO2 conversion). The coke deposition profile of the Ru/20CeO2 catalyst was also analyzed to assess the coke resistance of the catalyst and the results obtained were quite impressive; there was minimal formation of coke throughout the 18 h DRM test. On the other hand, the Ni/20CeO2 catalyst began to form coke at a very fast rate within the same time as the Ni/10CeO2 catalyst. To evaluate the effectiveness of Ru-containing catalyst, a 120 h stability test was carried out on Ru/CeO2 catalyst. The catalyst was proved to have good stability and reactivity on the DRM test and there was no observable deactivation of the catalyst throughout the 120 h of the test. The conversion of CH4 was at 58 % that of CO2 at 71 %, and the H2/CO ratio was 0.87 with no sign of coke, which was favorable. The authors attributed this to the fact that, high rate of CH4 dissociation over Ni catalysts left CH* and C* species in the state of poor oxidation on the catalyst surface. On the other hand, CH4 dissociation was slower on Ru which allowed for the timely conversion of CH* and C* to CHO* and CO species. This mechanism greatly improves the coke resistance of the Ru/CeO2 catalyst. Furthermore, DFT calculations and temperature-programmed surface reaction studies have revealed that Ru clusters on ceria surfaces lower the activation barrier for CO2 dissociation by ∼0.6 eV compared to Ni, facilitating the formation of reactive surface carbonates that readily oxidize carbon deposits [198]. Another reason that authors propose for the excellence of Ru/20CeO2 catalytic activity is the use of hydrothermal method for the synthesis of this catalyst. Rapid nucleation assisted by microwave emission and carbon frame from glucose formed metal-support interaction at the interface and acquire even distribution of Ru on the catalyst. Another innovation used in this work is that both Ru/20CeO2 and Ni/20CeO2 didn't need H2 reduction in order to achieve high conversion of catalyst. Instead of that, the metallic phases in Ru/20CeO2 and Ni/20CeO2 reduced by glucose. To examine the effect of Ru content on catalyst performance, Ru catalysts supported on CeO2 with varying Ru to CeO2 ratios were tested: Ru/5CeO2, Ru/20CeO2, and Ru/100CeO2. Ru/5CeO2 exhibited approximately 58 % CH4 conversion, 73 % CO2 conversion, and a H2/CO ratio of 0.85. However, increasing the Ru loading did not lead to improved catalytic efficiency. Surprisingly, Ru/20CeO2 demonstrated the best performance among the tested catalysts. On the other hand, when the Ru to CeO2 ratio decreased to 1:100 in Ru/100CeO2, the catalyst did not exhibit the expected catalytic activity in DRM. The CH4 and CO2 conversions were only 39 % and 57 %, respectively, and these values further decreased to 16.4 % and 33.4 % after an 18 h time on stream. 5 Reduced solid solution catalyst Reduced solid solution catalysts are in nature different from supported catalysts because the active phase is derived from the solid solution bulk rather than an additional species. This allows to form a broad active metallic particle with small sizes and super strong interaction with solid solution matrix. Because of this, active metallic particles will be protected from aggregation and oxidation which resulting in high activity and extraordinary carbon-deposition resistance and excel stability during DRM reaction [199]. The most promising group of this type of catalyst is MgO based solid solution catalyst which researchers succeeded to achieve great activity and stability with them. 5.1 MgO based solid solution catalyst Magnsium oxide (MgO) is known to be superior as a catalyst and support material because of its extraordinary basicity, thermal stability, and chemical neutrality. Exchanging MgO as an active site in a solid solution shows unique features such as different operating conditions than those of common heterogeneous catalysts. The solid solution solutions require the response of various metal oxides into one single crystalline phase exceeding better properties, enhanced catalytic activity and high stability. Moreover, in the context of Dry Reforming of Methane, the robust Lewis basicity exhibited by MgO facilitates a potent adsorption of CO2, potentially mitigating or impeding coke formation. Consequently, catalysts derived from a reduced solid solution incorporating an MgO matrix hold immense promise for DRM applications. Even though the first catalytic effect of MgO based catalyst goes back to 1928 [200] but the first high performance and efficient of a NiO-MgO solid solution catalyst was reported by Hu and ruckenstein [201] in 1995. In summary, they impregnated MgO in the aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2, followed by calcination at 800 °C in air and reduced in H2. the catalytic performance (98 % CO2 and 91 % CH4 conversions at 790 °C respectively,95 % And 91 % yields of CO and H2, respectively, and a high stability comes with little cocking) in a long 120 h TOS, was good and unprecedented until then. In a recent work, Danghyan et al. [199] prepared a series of Ni-supported on solid solution (NiOMgO) catalysts with varying Ni concentrations (10, 20, and 30 wt. %) using a novel paper-assisted combustion synthesis (PACS) method. PACS is the abbreviation of a method for preparing solid solution catalysts by using self-propagating combustion reaction. It begins with the synthesis of a reactive solution made of metal nitrate precursors and glycine that are soaked into cellulose filter paper. The impregnated paper is dried at 80 °C for 2 h and then heated on a hot plate to about 200 °C. This in turn results in the generation of self-heat which causes rapid combustion reaction throughout the paper to form the required solid solution. The process integrates templating property of cellulose, high exothermicity and high surface area catalysts with smaller crystallite sizes and minimal sintering. Under optimal PACS conditions, the solid solutions achieved high BET surface areas equal to 140 m²/g especially for one-step synthesis approach. In a 25 h DRM experiment in 700 °C, the conversion of CH4 and CO2 in the outlet stream with the 10 wt. % Ni sample was about 78 % and 93 % respectively. The advantage of this synthesis method which lead to a high-performance catalyst, comparing to other methods like co-precipitation and sol-gel, lies in higher surface area. For comparison, Zanganeh et al. [202] used a surfactant assisted co-precipitation method for synthesizing the same catalyst and the highest surface area they achieved was about 115 m²/g. Jafarbegloo et al. [203] with the help of sol-gel method were able to reach 161 m2/g surface area with the 5 % NiO/MgO but resulted in a lower conversion compare with Danghyan et al.’s work. This superiority seems to originating from the smaller Ni crystallite sizes, and an increased presence of Ni2+ and Ni3+ sites on the catalyst surface. An outlook to the published work with MgO based catalysts in the DRM reaction can be seen in Table 6 . Wang et al. [204] expanded our scope of knowledge with the coking process in a NiMgOx solid solution catalyst. The aim of their study was to examine the mechanisms of coke formation and identify optimal conditions to enhance catalytic performance and stability in the DRM over a NiMgOx catalyst. The DRM reaction was carried out using a synthesized NiMgOx catalyst containing MgNiO2 solid solution phase. By conducting a systematic study at the different reaction temperatures, the study was able to examine the growth of the catalyst, the catalytic activity, and the reaction mechanisms. In the used catalyst post-reaction, the existence of both metallic Ni0 sites and the solid solution phase was established. The evaluation revealed that the 650 °C activation maximized the synergistic dissociation of CH4 and CO2 while providing suitable conversion rates of nearly 72 % for CH4 and 76 % for CO2, the appropriate H2/CO ratio of 0.9, and stable anti-coke formation over 78 h TOS. On the other hand, at 550 °C, high coke formation and a high rate of catalyst deactivation within 9 h were observed due to the difference in the activation rate of CH4 and CO2. The study also examined two possible coking processes, which include CH4 decomposition and CO disproportionation at different temperatures. Endothermic CH4 decomposition at 650 °C showed high H2 production rates in the first minutes but resulted in intense coking, which was determined to be the primary mechanism responsible for coking. In the contrary, CO disproportionation at the same temperature showed low CO2 production rates and high coke graphitization, suggesting it could be eradicated as the main coking route. In-situ DRIFT spectra elucidated surface species during CO2 dissociation and DRM reactions over the NiMgOx catalyst at varying temperatures, highlighting the role of carbonates, bicarbonates, carboxylates, and formates. Specifically, at the optimal temperature of 650 °C, strong bands of bidentate and monodentate formates indicated easy desorption of both CH4 and CO2, favoring anti-coke DRM reactions over the NiMgOx catalyst. Chatla et al. [205] prepared a Ni-MgO solid solution catalyst with 13 wt. % Ni content and doped with various amount of Zr for the DRM reaction. Analysis of the reduced samples by TEM showed that the Zr-modified catalysts possess smaller Ni particle size compared to Ni/MgO while N2O-pulse chemisorption demonstrated higher Ni dispersion than Ni/MgO. The H2-TPR analysis as shown in the Fig. 19 was done on the calcined Ni/x%Zr/MgO catalysts to understand the effect of Zr content on Ni reduction and interaction with support. The reduction behavior of Ni/MgO and Ni/1Zr/MgO catalysts was characterized by a single broad reduction peak at around 800 °C suggesting a strong interaction of NiO with the support, while Ni/3Zr/MgO, Ni/5Zr/MgO and Ni/10Zr/MgO catalysts had three distinguishable reduction peaks in the range of 400–800 °C. The low-temperature reduction peak at 445 °C, for Zr containing catalysts, indicates partial reduction of ZrO2 at the Ni-ZrO2 interface and the peak intensity increases with Zr content. Moreover, the peak at higher temperature above 607 °C is associated to the interaction between NiO and ZrO2 while the high temperature reduction peak at 800 °C is ascribed to strong interaction NiO with the support. Notably, the magnitude in high temperature peak reduced with increase in Zr content and hence suggesting better Ni reducibility with Zr incorporation, especially about the MgO supported catalysts. This enhancement is owed to the acidic-basic features of the support where the presence of MgO-ZrO2 possesses higher basicity than MgO and hence, possess better interaction with the incorporated ZrO2 promoter for the reduction of NiO. In addition, the results obtained from CO2-TPD analysis confirmed the improvement in basicity and CO2 adsorption ability with the addition of Zr, which could be ascribed to the basic characteristic of ZrO2.Experimental DRM results (in 750 °C) highlighted Ni/3Zr/MgO (3 wt. % Zr) as the most active catalyst, maintaining stable conversion rates of CH4 (78 %), CO2 (91 %), and H2/CO ratio (0.92) in 70 h TOS without deactivation(the carbon deposition limited to only 7 %). CH4-Temperature Programmed Surface Reaction (TPSR) suggested that Zr promotion significantly reduces CH4 dissociation energy, possibly attributable to smaller Ni particles, robust metal-support interaction, and heightened Ni metal dispersion. In conclusion, MgO-based solid solution catalysts and specifically those containing NiO have shown favorable characteristics for use in DRM. The high basicity, thermal stability and the peculiar catalytic properties of MgO, along with the new synthesis techniques such as PACS have render the catalysts with high surface area, with small crystallite size and high resistance to coking. The incorporation of promoters like Zr has taken the catalytic performance to the next level especially through the reduction of particle size and improvement in the dispersion of the metal. In summary, MgO-based catalysts particularly with Ni solid solution exhibit high conversion and relatively long-term stability over DRM reactions with little deactivation. More studies are needed to understand the electrochemical processes that happen in coke formation and reduction. The development of reduced solid solution catalysts based on other metal oxides remains relatively unexplored, though it is not entirely untouched. One of metal oxides that has been studied is ceria based solid solution. In a recent work, in order to inspect the impact of oxygen vacancies on CO2 activation in the DRM reaction over ceria-based solid solutions catalyst, Wang et al. [218] synthesized a series of ceria-based solid solutions doped with aliovalent metal ions (La3+, Nd3+, Sm3+, and Eu3+). Among these metals, Eu resulted in slightly better conversions of reactants. Through a combination of transient response experiments and numerical simulations, they quantified the concentration and reactivity of oxygen vacancies, identifying them as crucial sites for direct CO2 dissociation. The findings revealed that substituting Ce4+ with trivalent ions increases oxygen vacancies, thereby enhancing CO2 activation and facilitating the oxidation of coke intermediates. The study highlighted the interaction between composition and catalytic behavior among ceria-based materials, showing that variations in dopant cations significantly influence DRM activity and redox behavior. Specifically, higher oxygen vacancy concentrations and reactivity correlated with improved redox properties and catalytic performance. 6 Special structures A variety of complex oxide materials with unique structures have shown great promise in the DRM reaction. Among these, pyrochlores, spinel oxides, and layered double hydroxides (LDHs) stand out due to their exceptional thermal stability, tunable surface properties, and ability to accommodate metal cations within their robust lattice structures. Even though many of the catalysts presented in the subsequent sections may fall into the reduced solid solution category (such as pyrochlores, spinel oxides and perovskites, where A or B site cations are partially substituted by other elements without significantly altering the crystal structure). However, due to the fixed and unsubstituted structures of certain materials, which do not fit the reduced solid solution category, and the presence of layered double hydroxide (LDH) materials, which also cannot be classified as reduced solid solutions at all, these materials are introduced separately here. These materials not only offer superior resistance to sintering and carbon deposition (one of major challenges in DRM catalysis) but also enable the fine-tuning of catalytic activity through structural modifications. Pyrochlores, for instance, are known for their high oxygen mobility and stable mixed-metal frameworks, which allow for the incorporation of active metals like nickel. Spinel oxides and LDHs also provide flexible platforms where the interaction between metal cations and the support can be tailored to enhance coke resistance and catalytic performance. In the upcoming sections, these materials and their applications in catalytic systems for DRM will be reviewed. 6.1 Pyrochlores Pyrochlore catalysts include a group of materials with the general formula A2B2O7 where A is a larger cation mostly a rare earth metal ion and B is a smaller cation mainly a transition metal ion and they have a high structural versatility. This flexibility also means that various metal ions can be incorporated into both the A and B positions and these substitutions can have a large impact on the catalytic activity of the material. For instance, the replacement of nickel (Ni) in lanthanum zirconate (La2Zr2O7) pyrochlores was found to increase the catalytic activity for DRM because of better dispersion of the metal and higher availability of active sites [219,220]. Precise control of the metal composition and the consequent electronic properties of the pyrochlore structure is a key factor for the efficient catalytic performance. Some research has shown that the Rh-doped pyrochlore catalysts like La2Zr2O7 with Rh-substitution have high activity in the DRM reaction. Polo-Garzon et al. [221] performed isotopic labeling experiments that support the proposed reaction mechanism for methane dehydrogenation and CO generation and further demonstrated that the addition of Rh improves the reaction rate. The results obtained from this study point to the possibility of enhancing the DRM process by incorporating noble metals such as Rh to activate methane. Besides noble metal doping, attempts have also been made to modify the Ni-substituted pyrochlore catalysts. provided on the preparation of Ni-doped La2(CeZrNi)2O7 pyrochlores, which showed how the adjustment of A and B site cations results in catalysts with different and favorable characteristics for DRM [222]. The study also focused on the metal loading and structural properties of the pyrochlore for the best catalytic activity. le Saché et al. [223] investigated the substitution of Zr by Ni at different loadings in the lanthanum zirconate pyrochlore (La2Zr2O7) in the various reaction conditions. The catalysts were prepared by citrate method which is a subset of sol-gel method. They synthesized catalysts with 0, 2, 5 and 10 wt. % Ni loading which named them LZ, LNZ2, LNZ5 and LNZ10 respectively. Before import the catalysts in DRM reaction, they execute an in-situ reduction under 50 vol % H2 in He, with temperature of 700 °C in 1 h. Then, the reaction was carried out for 30 h, at 1 atm pressure in the 600–700 °C temperature range. They used 0.100 g of catalyst for the activity tests. The 2 wt. % loaded catalyst was relatively inactive. The catalysts with loading bigger than 2 % showed activity during the DRM. Among them, LNZ10 exhibited the best catalytic activity and stability. It attained a conversion of 79 % for CO2 and 65 % for CH4 (Fig. 20 ) and get to steady state in less than 1 h with no deactivation was detected after 30 h on stream. It is worth mentioning that in all tests, the CO2 conversion was greater than CH4 due to reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) which reduce the energy barrier for activation of CO2 rather than CH4. In a related study, le Saché et al. [224]; the authors examined the efficiency of Ni promoted pyrochlore catalysts in the conversion of biogas in to syngas using DRM. Emphasis was laid on determining the impact of the change in the ratio of CH4/CO2 in biogas which mimics different waste biomass substrates. Two types of catalysts were tested: a pyrochlore with Ni doping and a pyrochlore with impregnated Ni. The results showed that the Ni-doped pyrochlore material had better stability and anti-sintering effect in the reaction of biogas mixtures with lower CH₄ concentration (CH4/CO2 ≤ 1.25). On the other hand, both catalysts rapidly deactivated when the concentration of CH₄ in biogas surpassed 60 %, consequently, carbon deposition was promoted. The results of TGA analysis proved that the Ni-doped pyrochlore catalyst had better resistance to carbon formation than the Ni-impregnated catalyst. The findings of this study affirmed that the ability to stabilize Ni in the pyrochlore structure is important for enhancing coke resistance particularly under methane rich environment. This work focus on the pyrochlore catalyst for biogas upgrading because of the outstanding stability and low carbon deposition in different biogas compositions. Bhattar et al. [225], studied the effect of substitution of La by Sr and Ca in an already Ni substituted lanthanum zirconate pyrochlore catalysts for the DRM reaction. For start, they prepared La2Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LNZ6), La1.95Ca0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LCNZ6), La1.95Sr0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LSNZ6) by pechini method. Then, they tested these catalysts under the condition as follows; a 100 h DRM at 800 °C temperature with an 18 L.h-1gcat -1 GHSV and 1 atm pressure. The results are shown in Fig. 21 . Existence of NiO and La-Ni perovskite phase in all Ni substituted catalysts promote the bounded solubility of Ni in the pyrochlore framework. LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 which was the Ca and Sr substituted catalysts respectively, resulted in a highly abiding La2NiZrO6 perovskite phase which the LNZ6 was in lack of this feature. As it is obviously can be concluded from Fig. 21, the LSNZ6 catalyst had a superior catalytic activity than LCNZ6 and LNZ6 during the DRM reaction circumstances. The authors specify that this excellence is due to the better Ni surface coverage (observed from XPS) and a smaller particle size with high dispersion (observed from SEM-EDS, XRD and TPR.) also it has worth mentioning that with all catalysts there was not significant sintering of the active metal sites. This claim is supported by TPO and HRTEM which although, showed carbon formation, but catalysts stability did not affect by that. Martín-Espejo et al. [226] studied the effect of the nickel-based cerium zirconate inorganic complex structure as a catalyst. Their research investigated the impact of dissolving various amounts of Ni (from 0 to 15 %) into the cerium zirconate lattice and its stability and catalytic activity. From the XRD and TPR analysis it could be inferred that Ni incorporation has altered the crystal structure and hence different catalytic phases exist. Among the catalysts prepared, the 10 wt. % Ni-loaded catalyst showed the optimal performance, with the stability of the catalytic activity being maintained at 100 h at high temperatures of 600 and 800 °C. This robust behavior thus demonstrates how Ni has helped in improving the DRM performance and eliminate problems such as sintering and carbon deposition. In a 2024 published study, Liu et al. [227] conducted a study on enhancing the coking resistance and catalytic performance of Ni/A2Ti2O7 pyrochlore catalysts through A-site doping with La and Gd for DRM. Their work builds on prior research into pyrochlore catalysts by introducing A-site modifications to improve the balance between methane decomposition and CO₂ activation, a key issue affecting DRM catalysts. The primary contribution of this study is the development of a strategy to modify the A-site of the A2Ti2O7 structure, which enhances the production of surface oxygen species responsible for eliminating carbon deposition during DRM. This contrasts with earlier works, such as those involving Rh-substituted pyrochlores, by utilizing more cost-effective transition metals like Ni. Compared to previous studies focusing on noble metals (such as Rh and Pt) for DRM, which offered excellent activity but high costs, Liu et al. provide an economically feasible alternative by demonstrating that moderate doping with Gd or La significantly boosts methane and CO2 conversions. Specifically, their 2 % Gd-doped Ni-La2Ti2O7 catalyst achieved CH4 and CO2 conversions of 70.8 % and 86.6 %, respectively, over 200 h at 800 °C, with negligible carbon deposition. This level of performance is on par with, if not superior to, noble metal-based catalysts while being more affordable. A key difference from prior works lies in their approach to modulating the electronic properties of the pyrochlore structure through A-site doping. The study revealed that this modification improves the adsorption capacity for CO2 and facilitates the activation of CH bonds in methane, thereby reducing the formation of undesirable carbon deposits. This finding contrasts with other studies that primarily focused on tuning metal loadings and structural characteristics. Moreover, Liu et al. expanded the body of knowledge by showing that excessive doping can lead to over-saturation, reducing catalytic efficiency, thus underscoring the need for precise optimization (Table 7 ). 6.2 Spinel oxides Spinel oxides are a class of compounds with the general formula AB2×4, where A and B are metal cations, and X is typically oxygen, though it can also be sulfur or selenium. These compounds crystallize in a cubic close-packed structure, where the anions form a nearly close-packed array, and the cations occupy specific interstitial positions [233,234]. The crystal structure can be visualized as consisting of two types of interstitial sites: tetrahedral sites occupied by A cations and octahedral sites occupied by B cations [235]. A simplified illustration of different type of spinel structures is portrayed in Fig. 22 . The outstanding thermal stability, high mechanical strength, and inertness to sintering make them ideally applied in high-temperature conditions. In addition, spinel oxides may also have a large specific surface area and possess several oxidation states favoring redox reactions that are of importance in almost all catalytic processes. The tunable electronic and structural properties of spinel oxides allow them to perform catalytic activities in a large number of reactions. In each and every one of them, oxygen reduction and evolution, CO oxidation, and organic transformations are included. Spinel oxides are very compatible with applications in reactions such as dry reforming of methane. Very high resistance to periodic changes in temperature can assure their work under very high temperatures in the DRM process. The resistance to deposition of carbon, quite usual in DRM processes, actually prolongs the lifetime and maintains the efficiency of catalysts. Spinel oxides present immunity toward carbon deposition, which is contributed to several reasons for the nature of catalyst efficiency during DRM reaction. The strong crystal lattice and high thermal stability along with intrinsic structural properties of spinel oxides are responsible for the nonformation of carbonaceous deposits. The mixed oxidation states of the metal cations of the spinel oxides invoke the redox cycling and promote oxidative removal of species of carbon over the surface of catalysts. Due to the existence of a large number of oxygen vacancies, a very high oxygen mobility is achieved in the spinel oxides, allowing the surface oxygen to be continuously replenished. The dynamic oxygen exchange has a critical role in the oxidation and removal of carbon deposits to keep a catalytically active surface. High scattering of active sites on the spinel oxide surface makes carbon formation negligible. The use of transition metals such as nickel (Ni) or cobalt (Co) will cause the coked catalyst to exhibit increased resistance to coking because of the further gasification of deposited carbon by the Boudouard reaction or steam reforming reaction in order to decrease the interaction between growing carbon particles [236–239]. These properties, in conjunction with the intrinsic stability and redox activity of spinel oxides, lead to superior carbon deposition resistance not only in DRM but also in other high-temperature catalytic processes. The possibility of entering various metal cations into the spinel structure offers ways for fine-tuning the nature of sites and catalytic sites in the optimization of activity and selectivity. Spinel oxides efficiently facilitate the activation and dissociation of CH4 and CO2 due to their mixed oxidation states and a large area. This increases the overall catalytic performance and hence the efficiency of the DRM process. Among all types of spinales, MgAl2O4 especially with Ni as the metal phase, has garnered the most attention for a catalyst candidate in a DRM reaction. There is considerable research on the use of spinel oxides in DRM with a number of synthesis techniques used in an attempt to fine tune the performance of the catalysts. Some of the synthesis methods used are sol-gel, co-precipitation, hydrothermal synthesis and thermal impregnation. These methods enable precise control over the crystalline structure and surface characteristics of the spinel, which are key factors with regard to the improvement of catalytic performance and stabilities. It has been shown that spinel oxides prepared using these techniques provide better resistance to carbon deposition and sulfur poisoning important for sustainable DRM operation. All such synthesis methods have provided spinels of high surface area, evenly distributed metal sites and appropriate redox properties for efficient catalytic reactions. The following section explains the extent of the use of spinel based catalysts under different DRM conditions in detail. Misture et al. [240] examined the applicability of spinel-based catalysts for the dry reforming of methane. The catalysts were prepared in the form of (M0.75Mg0.25) Al2O4 where M is Ni, Co or Cu and the catalysts were prepared by thermal impregnation. This process involved high temperature treatment at 1300 °C to 1600 °C, resulting to highly crystalline spinels with good faceting which is essential in catalytic applications. Catalytic performance was evaluated at 850 °C and results indicated that the catalysts, especially Ni0.375Cu0.375Mg0.25Al2O4 maintained constant methane conversion efficiency for 12 h without much coking formation. The data obtained in the experiments showed that the Ni0.375Cu0.375Mg0.25Al2O4 catalyst retained its methane conversion efficiency of 25 % after 12 h of reaction while Ni0.75Mg0.25Al2O4 had higher initial conversion of 96 % and was slightly lower at 92 % after 3 h. At 20 ppm H2S, the catalysts synthesized at higher temperatures including Ni0.75Mg0.25Al2O4 treated at 1500 °C, showed better sulfur tolerance in terms of much lesser reduction in the conversion rate. Moreover, the catalysts were found to possess full regeneration capacity after being subjected to sulfur poisoning and it was evident that oxidative treatment followed by reduction brought the catalytic efficiency to almost the initial level and in some instances, the performance was even enhanced after regeneration. The high catalytic activity of spinel oxides in DRM is due to their sharp faceting which provides large number of reactive sites at the edges and corners of metal crystallites. These undercoordinated sites improve the activation of methane. The structure of spinel is defective which provides large capacity for oxygen storage and redox cycling to continuously remove carbon deposits and keep the surface active. Furthermore, the introduction of Mg enhances the sulfur tolerance by enhancing the oxidative removal of sulfur species by CO2 activation. It also improves the performance by avoiding the formation of metal-sulfide and the enhancement of sulfur removal the Ni/Co ratio. As indicated in the previous works, the choice of proper synthesis routes for spinel oxides is crucial for preparing materials with desired crystalline structures and surface characteristics of the catalysts. Such techniques as thermal impregnation and sol-gel methods have proved crucial in synthesizing spinels with high catalytic activity and regeneration capacity as shown in the study above. The reusability of the catalysts after sulfur poisoning along with improved redox properties offers potential for long-term catalytic use in DRM. Subsequently, more study has been directed to alloy catalysts with a view of enhancing coke resistance, a key issue in methane reforming, through the control of Ni-Co alloy systems. Hyun Kim et al. [241] synthesized Ni-Co alloy catalysts from NixCoy/MgAl2O4 by exsolution process for high coke resistance catalyst in DRM reaction. The catalysts comprised of different Ni ratios which were Ni2Co1, Ni4Co1, Ni5Co1, and Ni4Co0. The DRM reactions were performed at temperatures of 650–800 °C with a GHSV of 105 L⋅gcat −1⋅h −1. Before the reaction, the catalysts were reduced at 800 °C in a 4 % H2/Ar mixed gas for 2 h. The conversion of CH4 was found to be slightly lower than that of CO2 at all the temperatures and the highest conversion of CH4 was observed with Ni4Co1 catalyst. As the temperature increased, the CO2 conversion rates were close to the thermodynamic limit consequently suggesting enhanced DRM facilitation. The Ni4Co1 catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity (around 90 % for both reactants) and stability; the activity was maintained throughout the 100 h test, with a coking rate of only 0. 2 μgcoke⋅gcat -1⋅h-1. The Ni5Co1 catalyst which initially has high activity lost its activity after 29.7 h due to coke formation, similarly Ni4Co0 catalyst lost its activity in 5.6 h due to severe coking. The reason for the high activity of the Ni4Co1 and Ni2Co1 catalysts is the balance between CH4 and CO2 activation due to the presence of Co improving the total basicity of the catalyst and increasing the efficiency of CO2 activation and coke resistance. In-situ DRIFT analysis of the Ni-Co alloy catalysts showed that anti-coking was due to a formate-intermediate dominant pathway which was not observed in the monometallic Ni catalysts. The total basicity and the bidentate carbonate species content in Ni-Co alloy catalysts were higher according to the CO2-TPD analysis, which is why the catalysts demonstrated better coke resistance. Ni-Co alloy catalysts are then shown to be highly effective for DRM reactions with the Ni4Co1 catalyst being the most effective due to its increased coke resistance and more stable reaction pathways. Sajjadi et al. [242] explored the synthesis and performance of Co-promoted Ni-spinel nanocatalysts using combustion, sol-gel, and hybrid sol-gel plasma methods for combined reforming of CH4/CO2/O2. The objective of the study was to generate hydrogen and syngas and at the same time reduce the formation of coke. The best catalytic activity was obtained with the nanocatalysts synthesized using the sol-gel plasma (SGP) method compared to the sol-gel method (Table 8 ), with the CH4 conversion rate reached 96.5 % at 850 °C. The tests were performed at different conditions as follows GHSV of 24 L/gcat⋅h and feed ratio of CH4/CO2/O2=1/1/0.08. The nanocatalyst has a long-term stability in terms of catalytic activity, with no significant decrease in activity in 48 h at 750 °C and, at the same time, the coke deposition is also minimal and the H2/CO ratio is close to 1. Several factors were highlighted for the high performance and stability of the NCA (SGP) catalyst as follows. Sol-gel plasma method developed nanocatalysts with large BET surface area (261 m2/g), robust metal-support interaction, and high reducibility. These characteristics were further supported by BET and TPR analysis. The plasma treatment improved the distribution of the active metal particles and minimized the possibility of their aggregation as observed from the FESEM and EDX investigations. According to the findings of the study, the sol-gel plasma method is useful for preparing highly active and coke-resistant nanocatalysts for the integrated reforming of methane, carbon dioxide and oxygen. In the long way of promoting a Ni based MgAl2O4 catalyst, Khoja et al. [243] studied the possibility of employing a support modified Ni/La2O3–MgAl2O4 catalyst in DRM with a Dielectric Barrier Discharge Plasma Reactor. This catalyst was prepared by a modified co-precipitation assisted hydrothermal method which resulted in better dispersion of Ni phase and better interaction with the support La2O3-MgAl2O4. As is already understood, the electron configuration and structural characteristics of the Ni atoms in the catalyst play a significant role in the performance of the catalyst. Ni atoms in their zero oxidation state enable the dissociative chemisorption of CH4 by providing a pathway of low activation energy. La2O3 incorporates fundamental sites that greatly improve CO2 adhesion and activation and create intermediate carbonates (La2O2CO3); the carbon deposits interact with these intermediates to restore La2O3 and reduce carbon accumulation. The best performance of the catalyst was CH4 and CO2 conversion of 86 % and 84 %. Respectively, at certain reaction conditions; GHSV=364 h-1, a temperature as low as 350 °C and 15 h TOS. Cobalt and La2O3 work together to not only promote the dispersion of Ni particles so that they will not be agglomerated and sintered, but also improve the dielectric properties of the catalyst. This leads to an improved electric field in the plasma discharge zone which enhances the DRM overall performance. The increase in basicity by La2O3 also helps in the generation of reactive oxygen species which in turn helps in the activation of CO2 and gasification of carbon formed on the catalyst surface thus ensuring longer life of the catalyst and high conversion efficiency. Studies focusing on exsolution synthesis methods, along with alloy formation, have enabled the development of catalysts that not only demonstrate high coke resistance but also exhibit enhanced performance in prolonged reaction times. These findings emphasize the importance of optimizing both the alloy composition and the synthesis technique to achieve superior catalytic results. With the increased understanding of formate-intermediate pathways in DRM, future research should aim at further refining synthesis techniques to develop even more stable and efficient spinel-based catalysts for industrial applications. Herwig et al. [244] performed a comprehensive research on the use of hierarchically structured spinel based catalysts, specifically on NiAl2O4 and CoAl2O4 systems. The catalysts were prepared using epoxide-mediated sol-gel process in conjunction with the polymerization-induced phase separation to achieve a high surface area and hierarchical pore structure. This synthesis method greatly improved the dispersion of the active phase, and thereby the formation of agglomerates was avoided and Ni was incorporated into the alumina matrix without generating bulk NiO. In experiments, Herwig et al. investigated the catalysts with 4 mol % Ni (4Ni-H) under different reaction conditions. The DRM reaction was performed at 1023 K, 1073 K and 1123 K with an overall GHSV of 6000h-1. The 4 Ni-H catalyst had good catalytic activity; the CH4 conversion rates were 62 % at 1023 K, 80 % at 1073 K, and 90 % at 1123 K, near the thermodynamic limit of 94.6 % at 1123 K because of the catalyst's hierarchical pore structure, which improved the reactant diffusion and interaction. They also compared NiAl2O4 with noble metal containing catalysts like Rh containing variants of the same. It was noted that, the noble metal-free NiAl2O4 catalyst could reach the similar or even higher CH4 conversion while possessing a lower risk of coking formation, which is one of the major challenges in DRM reactions. In particular, the hierarchical NiAl2O4 spinel catalysts had a lower Csel, which was 3.5 times smaller as compared with the Rh-doped materials. This is attributed to the dispersion of Ni and the hierarchical pore structure which helps in minimizing the formation of carbon on the catalyst surface. Zhang et al. [245] developed a new nanocomposite catalyst of quasi-monolayer Rh clusters anchored on spinel MgAl2O4 nanosheets at a low Rh content of 0.15 wt % (Rh/MgAl2O4-MC). This structural design allows for nearly full utilization of Rh atoms, comparable to single-atom catalysts, and while maintaining the durability of the support nanoparticles. The catalyst was characterized for its ability to perform in DRM reaction. The reaction circumstances included temperature range of 450 °C to 750 °C and GHSV of 36 L. g-1. h −1. The Rh/MgAl2O4-MC catalyst exhibited high specific reaction rates of CH4 and CO2 at 750 °C equal to 51.14 mol molRh-1s-1 and 62.65 mol molRh-1s-1, respectively. These rates are 4.7 and 4.8 times higher than those observed over the conventional Rh nanoparticles supported on MgAl2O4 nanosheets with higher Rh content, which is 0.96 wt %. TOFs for CH4 and CO2 over Rh/MgAl2O4-MC were significantly high, 53.9 s-1 and 66.1 s-1, respectively which were 3.5 times higher than that of the conventional catalyst. The superior catalytic performance observed with Rh/MgAl2O4-MC in this study is attributed to its unique nanocomposite design, where the interaction between the Rh quasi-monolayer clusters and MgAl2O4 support stabilizes Rh clusters and reduces the activation energies of the DRM reaction. This is a clear demonstration of how spinel-based catalysts, with fine control over metal-support interactions, enhance the catalytic efficiency.
