The following section focuses on stability tests of this catalyst, which further emphasizes its long-term viability in high-temperature reactions. It can be concluded that the enhanced performance of the Rh/MgAl2O4-MC catalyst is due to the strong interaction between the Rh quasi-monolayer clusters and the MgAl2O4 support which not only stabilizes the energetically unfavorable Rh clusters but also considerably decreases the activation energies of the rate determining steps of the DRM reaction. This interaction enhances the conversion rate of CHx species to COx species, enhances the inherent catalytic activity and reduces the tendency of carbon formation. The Rh/MgAl2O4-MC catalyst was further subjected to long-term stability tests at 750 °C for 100 h TOS where both the catalysts were able to achieve a high conversion of around 92 % for CO2 and 87 % for CH4 in the outlet stream with minimal deactivation. Transitioning to the study by De Coster et al. [246] the focus shifts to promoting nickel-based catalysts with iron to enhance catalytic stability. The effectiveness of incorporating Fe into Ni/MgAl2O4 catalysts introduces a new alloy structure that further demonstrates how synthesis methods and bimetallic compositions contribute to better DRM performance, particularly in preventing carbon deposition. De Coster et al. studied the effect of promoting Ni/MgAl2O4 with Fe. They also identified that 8Ni5Fe/MgAl2O4 bimetallic catalyst has the best reaction activity and stability under practical conditions, which include 750 °C in temperature, 4580 h-1 in GHSV, and a CH4/CO2 molar ratio of 1/1. The catalyst was synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation and its phases were investigated by in situ QXAS and Mössbauer spectroscopy. The authors noted that, during the DRM reaction, Ni-Fe alloy from the reduction of NiFe2O4 and MgFe3+ x Al2-xO4 was formed. This alloy was important in sustaining high activity and minimizing carbon deposition mainly because of the redox ability of the Fe species that inhibited carbon formation. The formation of Ni-Fe alloys during DRM reactions offers key insights into how specific alloy compositions contribute to high catalytic activity by reducing carbon deposition. The Mars-van Krevelen mechanism highlighted in this study showcases how Fe's redox properties sustain catalyst stability, which is further investigated in the following studies exploring alternative synthesis methods for nickel-based catalysts on MgAl2O4 supports. In the study that recently conducted by Fuli Wen et al. [247], the catalysts used for the dry reforming of methane were Ni-based catalysts supported on MgAl2O4, prepared using a modified evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method and calcined at different temperatures (600 °C, 800 °C, and 1000 °C). The numbers following the catalyst names (Ni-MgAl2O4–600, Ni-MgAl2O4–800, Ni-MgAl2O4–1000) indicate these calcination temperatures. Ni-MgAl2O4–600 exhibited the largest specific surface area (283 m²/g), enhancing Ni dispersion and resulting in smaller Ni particle sizes, but it lacked an ordered mesoporous structure, leading to weak metal-support interactions and significant sintering over time. Ni-MgAl2O4–800 displayed an ordered mesoporous structure, providing strong confinement effects on Ni particles and strong metal-support interactions, with a specific surface area of 247 m²/g. This structure allowed the catalyst to maintain high conversions of CH4 and CO2 (both around 90 %) over 500 h, with minimal carbon deposition and slow grain growth, demonstrating excellent long-term stability and resistance to sintering and carbon deposition. Ni-MgAl2O4–1000 had the lowest specific surface area (98 m²/g) and lacked an ordered mesoporous structure, resulting in larger Ni particles from the start and rapid deactivation due to significant carbon deposition and sintering during long-term stability tests. The differences in these catalysts highlight that Ni-MgAl2O4–800, prepared at 800 °C, provided the best balance of properties, combining high activity with excellent long-term stability, thanks to its ordered mesoporous structure and strong metal-support interactions. Fig. 23 shows the results of this work and is a firm proof to the outstanding performance of the catalyst. The comparative analysis of the three calcined catalysts shows how changes in temperature during catalyst preparation affect the surface area, the dispersion of Ni, and the stability of the catalyst. Well-ordered mesoporous structure of Ni-MgAl2O4–800 contributes to the high performance and low deactivation during the long-term DRM tests. These findings are supplement by the following study, which extend the present work to investigate various synthesis techniques including co-precipitation and hydrothermal methods in nickel based catalysts. Benrabaa et al. [248] studied nickel ferrite (NiFe2O4) as a catalyst precursor. The catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation using NaOH or NH4OH and then calcined or by hydrothermal method with no need for calcination. The CP-Na-650, CP-Na-750, and CP-Na-850 catalysts, synthesized using NaOH coprecipitation and calcined at 650 °C, 750 °C, and 850 °C, respectively, had very low specific surface areas (<4 m²/g), higher crystallite sizes (23 nm to 77 nm) and higher Fe(III) content. These catalysts had low CH4 and CO2 conversion in the initial stage, and low conversion even after H2 pre-reduction due to their low activity, sintering and reducibility. The co-precipitation method as mentioned earlier is simple, but the synthesized catalysts possess low surface area and large crystallite size that hinder the catalytic performance. This is in contrast with the hydrothermal synthesis method which yields catalysts with larger surface area and improved performance. The hydrothermal approach is a major improvement to the preparation of the catalyst for DRM as will be discussed in the following sections on the impact of Mg/Al ratios and other modifications to the synthesis process. Nguyen-Phu et al. [249] studied the catalytic performance of NiMgAl mixed oxide catalysts with emphasis on the changes of the Mg/Al ratio in the catalyst system. The Ni-Mg1.5AlOx catalyst made out of co-precipitation had exceptional activity and stability. The experiments were performed in a flow tubular quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure and a GHSV of 120,000 mL/(gcat·h). The reactant gas mixture was CH4:CO2:N2 in a proportion of 4.5:4.5:1 ratio and the reaction was conducted at 900 K. Analysis of the long-term DRM tests revealed that the conversion of methane was found to be around 60 % while that of the carbon dioxide was 58 % approximately. Such performance was maintained and sustained throughout 120 h of operation. The improvement of the Ni-Mg1.5AlOx catalyst performance is directly related to the optimal value of the Mg/Al ratio that provides the balance between methane activation and coke deposition. The relationship between spinel and periclase phases demonstrates how catalyst composition influences activity and stability in DRM reactions, a topic analyzed in detail in Zhang et al.’s study of NixAlO2-δ catalysts. Zhang et al. [250] explored the catalytic performance of NixAl1O2-δ mesoporous catalysts for DRM, emphasizing the role of the NiAl2O4 spinel phase. The subscript numbers in the catalyst names (e.g., Ni0.05Al1O2-δ) denote the molar ratio of nickel to aluminum in the catalyst. For instance, Ni0.05Al1O2-δ means that the catalyst composition has 0.05 mol of Ni per mole of Al2O3. This ratio affects the characteristics of the catalyst such as the dispersion of nickel nanoparticles and the synthesis of the NiAl2O4 spinel phase. The symbol “δ” refers to oxygen vacancies in the structure that play a critical role in the catalytic performance of materials, especially in redox applications such as DRM. These vacancies assist to activate CO2 and remove carbon deposits leading to an improvement in the efficiency and stability of the catalyst. The catalysts were prepared by citric acid sol-gel method and the Ni content varied for the prepared catalysts. The DRM reaction was performed in a fixed bed reactor at 800 °C with GHSV of 108,000 mL/(h⋅gcat) using the reactant gas mixture of CH4:CO2:N2= 1. 5:1. 5:7. In the long term stability test, all the catalysts except Ni0.01Al1O2-δ have attained 91–92 % of CH4 conversion, 96.5–97.8 % of CO2 conversion and the H2/CO ratio is around 0.95. These conversions were sustained over 50 h emphasizing on the stability and coking of the catalysts. The best result achieved with the Ni0. 05Al1O2-δ catalyst is due to the formation of small Ni nanoparticles from the partially reduced NiAl2O4 spinel structure, which promotes the metal-support interaction and high dispersion of active sites. The systematic exploration of the NiAl2O4 spinel phase in Zhang et al.’s study highlights the critical role of oxygen vacancies and their impact on DRM activity. These findings are complemented by studies focusing on Ni nanoparticle formation and metal-support interactions, which further extend the understanding of how NiAl2O4 spinels enhance catalytic stability and resistance to coking. Muzafar Abbas et al. [251] investigated a hydrotalcite-derived NiAl2O4 spinel catalysts. The catalysts with different ratios of Mg:Ni:Al were synthesized via co-precipitation. The DRM reactions were performed in a quartz fixed-bed reactor under a GHSV of 40,000 mL/(gcat·h). The two catalysts performed well during the long term stability studies conducted at 850 °C, with the CH4 and CO2 conversion rates retaining around 90 % and 99 %, respectively after 200 h of TOS. The high activity and stability of the catalysts are due to the formation of Ni0 nanoparticles on the tips of carbon nanofibers (CNFs) that grown from the NiAl2O4 spinel phase through reduction. These Ni0 sites improve the interaction of metal and the support which results in high resistance to sintering and coking. The novelty of this study is the formation of stable spinel structures by using Mg-Ni-Al compositions and the eruption of CNF during the DRM process that has not been seen in earlier researches. These structural features were found to be responsible for the long-term stability and activity of the present catalyst which could be viewed as a major improvement over the conventional DRM catalysts due to the minimized carbon deposition and the enhanced catalytic activity. A study done by Alabi et al. [252] studied the impact of spinel inversion and metal-support interaction on the site activity of Mg-Al-Ox supported Co catalyst for CO2 reforming of CH4. This work presented an investigation into the change of support from Al-Ox to Mg-Al-Ox and demonstrated that there are major changes in the structure and function of the catalysts. The shifting of the hysteresis loop from H2 to H4 was also seen in the N2 adsorption data due to the incorporation of MgO and another phase of MgO was identified from the XRD pattern. The spinel phase decreased from 100 % to 45 % with the presence of Mg and this led to spinel inversion and changed the coordination of Mg and Al as indicated by K-edge XANES. The study revealed that in the case of Co catalysts, the active sites were well dispersed on the support while in the case of Ni catalysts the active sites were clustered with isolated NiO phases. The uniformity in Co distribution led to higher conversion rate for CO2 and CH4 in DRM and improved resistance to deactivation. The Co-Mg-Al-Ox catalyst exhibited higher efficiency in the conversion of CO2 and CH4 with 83 % and 80 % conversion efficiencies at 750 °C and at a GHSV of 1.2 × 106 mL/gcat/h over a period of 15 h of TOS. The turnover frequency calculations also supported the fact that Co-Mg-Al-Ox possessed higher site activity than Ni-Mg-Al-Ox and the other investigated catalysts. The addition of MgO into the support introduced spinel inversion, where the coordination environment changed of Mg and Al; this allowed a better distribution of Co active sites in comparison with the distribution of Ni sites. 6.3 LDHs Layered Double Hydroxides (LDHs) or hydrotalcite-like compounds (HTs), are a family of anionic clays with a unique layered structure that is built up from positively charged metal hydroxide layers and charge-balancing interlayer anions/ water molecules. In the hydrotalcite brucite-like (Mg(OH)2) layers, some of the divalent magnesium cations are isomorphously replaced by trivalent aluminum cations, likely because Mg2+ and Al3+ have similar ionic radii. This substitution causes the brucite-like layers to become positively charged. The positive charge is balanced by carbonate anions in the interlayer spaces, with water molecules filling the remaining voids between the hydrotalcite layers [253,254]. These materials, with the general formula of [M 1−x 2+Mx 3+(OH)2] x +[An−]x/n⋅mH2O,(where A refers to a monovalent cation), exhibit tunable anion exchange ability. The synthesis of LDHs involves techniques such as co-precipitation [255], hydrothermal synthesis [256], and the sol-gel method [257]. These materials possess many potential applications in catalysis, environmental remediation, drug delivery, electronics, flame retardants, CO2 capture and sensors. During thermal treatment, LDHs are converted into mixed metal oxides which exhibit high surface areas, well-dispersed active metal sites and improved redox properties to exhibit remarkable catalytic activity toward DRM. The hydrotalcite precursors produce mixed oxides, which limit sintering and are active in a variety of reaction conditions due to their high thermal stability. Replacing some or all of the Mg2+ cations with Ni2+ in the Mg/Al-CO3 hydrotalcite structure creates a catalytic system that, after calcination, is suitable for use in DRM [258]. Kalai et al. [259] investigated employing Ni(Mg)-Al hydrotalcite derived catalysts and contrasted them with catalysts synthesized utilizing the conventional incipient wetness impregnation. DRM experiments were performed at a very high GHSV of 240,000ml/(gcat h) at 750 °C. It was found that the 20Ni-Mg-AlHT catalyst displayed very high and steady conversion of both CH4 and CO2, whereas, the 12Ni-AlHT catalyst exhibited low activity because of the fluctuating Ni particles. Higher stability of the 20Ni-Mg-AlHT was due to the lack of fine particles of both Mg and Al in the HT structure and smaller Ni particles. These catalysts were also tested under various types of biogas and they all proved to be highly efficient even in the absence of CO2. The work by Kalai et al. gives insights into the impact of particle size and catalyst homogeneity on the activity and durability of DRM catalysts. The 20Ni-Mg-AlHT system contains smaller Ni particles and demonstrates better metal-support interaction to avoid deactivation processes such as sintering that is present in typical catalysts. These results confirm the significance of uneven distribution of metal in increasing the DRM activity especially when working under varying gas concentrations like in the case of biogas. In the next steps, the impact of the synthesis methods of the catalysts on the thermal stability and reducibility of the metals will be investigated in detail. Abdelsadek et al. [260] prepared NiAl-hydrotalcite (NiAl-HT) derived catalysts by co-precipitation at pH 11 and calcination at 450 °C for 6 h. Catalytic activity of the prepared catalyst in the DRM reaction was determined at varying temperatures. The initial conversion of CH4 and CO2 was 14.2 % and 18.3 %, respectively at 500 °C and there was no carbon deposition of the reaction due to the highly endothermic nature of the DRM reaction. As the temperature rose to 700 °C, conversions of CH4 were 87 % and CO2 were 85 % because the catalyst had a higher surface area and better reducibility of NiO to Ni. The second cycle of DRM after in-situ hydrogasification enhanced the conversion of CH4 and CO2 by 15.7 % and 17.3 % and H2/CO ratio by 14 %. This work's results demonstrate the crucial role of thermal treatment and hydrogen regeneration in sustaining catalytic activity. The improvement in NiO reducibility at higher temperatures directly correlates with increased conversion rates, highlighting the necessity of well-reduced active metal sites for effective CH4 activation. The second cycle's improved performance following hydrogasification illustrates how hydrogen plays a dual role in both removing carbonaceous deposits and regenerating Ni active sites, which is critical for long-term catalytic stability. The next investigation will delve into the impact of promoter elements such as Ce and Zr on catalyst reducibility and coking resistance. The influence of Ce, Zr, and Ce-Zr promotion on NiMgAl hydrotalcite-derived catalysts has been studied by Dębek et al. [261] for DRM at 500 °C. The catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation method and the Ni content was kept at 25 wt. %. The outcomes of the study showed that the incorporation of Ce and Zr made the catalysts more reducible and basic, which increased the CO2 adsorption and reduced the amount of carbon deposition. The Ce-promoted catalyst yielded the highest CO2 conversion since it had more oxygen vacancies while the Zr-promoted catalyst had the least carbon deposition resulting from formation of small Ni particles and increased BET surface area. The findings from Dębek et al. elucidate the crucial influence of metal promoters on both the catalytic performance and stability. The incorporation of Ce significantly boosts the generation of oxygen vacancies, which in turn enhances CO₂ activation, a known bottleneck in DRM processes. The role of Zr in reducing carbon deposition is closely tied to its ability to stabilize smaller Ni particles, which maintain a high dispersion and resist agglomeration under high-temperature conditions. This fine balance between promoter effects results in catalysts with improved resistance to carbon formation and overall stability. In the next section, the incorporation of Zn as a promoter to stabilize Ni particles and improve coking resistance will be examined in detail. Chatla et al. [262] investigated the effect of Zn promotion on the performance of NiMgAl catalyst for DRM at 650 °C. Zn-modified catalysts had higher and more stable reaction rates as compared to unmodified NiMgAl catalysts and among those NiMgAl-3 Zn had the highest CH4 and CO2 reaction rates of 0.1074 mol/min/gNi and 0.115 mol/min/gNi, respectively. This improvement was attributed to the reasons such as the presence of smaller Ni particles and stronger metal-support interaction in the presence of Zn that augmented CO2 adsorption and coking deactivation. The NiMgAl-3 Zn catalyst also proved to be rather stable exhibiting a constant H2/CO ratio of 0.87 in a 100 h test. Zn plays a critical role in forming highly dispersed Ni particles, which are known to possess higher catalytic activity and greater resistance to sintering, a common issue in DRM at elevated temperatures. The prolonged stability observed over the 100-h testing period suggests that Zn's promotional effect strengthens metal-support interactions, ensuring that the active sites remain exposed and functional. This result leads into the following exploration of how varying Ni loadings impact the dispersion and activity of Ni particles in LDH derived catalysts. Dębeka et al. [263] synthesized a series of hydrotalcite-derived catalysts based on the introduction of Ni2+ cations in the brucite-like layers at a different extent (5 %, 15 %, 25 %, 50 %, 75 %, and 100 %). These catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation from aqueous solutions of nickel, magnesium and aluminum nitrates, at pH = 10 with NaOH solution. The resulting suspension was aged, filtered and washed and dried before being calcined at 550 °C in air for 4 h to obtain mixed oxides known as HT-XNi, where X is the Ni content. According to the study, the incorporation of Ni2+ into the hydrotalcite structure changes the characteristics of the catalyst in comparison with the typical hydrotalcite catalysts applied in DRM. Some of these changes are improved dispersion of Ni and the support, as well as better interaction between Ni and the support, thus leading to improved catalytic activity and stability. The catalysts were tested for DRM under varying conditions: at temperatures between 500 °C and 750 °C, GHSV of 60,000 mL·g-1·h-1, and the CH4/CO2/N2 ratio of 1.5/1/7.5. The conversion rates for CH4 and CO2 were highest at 750 °C, being around 89 % for CH4, and 92 % for CO2 (when maintaining in 24 h time on stream) and the H2/CO ratio is slightly below 1. The high basicity of the catalysts, especially HT-25Ni, promotes the CO2 adsorption, as well as the subsequent CO2-consuming reactions, including DRM and the reverse Boudouard reaction. Further, Ni particles well dispersed and small in size promote methane decomposition and minimize carbon deposition. In the subsequent analysis, the stability of CoFe-based catalysts will be explored, particularly focusing on their ability to resist sintering and coke formation. A CoAl-LDH and CoFe-LDH hydrotalcite-like compounds were prepared by Aider et al. [264] by co-precipitation at pH 12. The synthesis process involved the addition of a mixture of metal nitrates to a vigorously stirred NaOH and Na2CO3 solution at room temperature and controlled pH. The precipitate was refluxed at 70 °C for 15 h, dried at 100 °C over night and lastly calcined at 800 °C for 6 h with the ramp of 5 °C per minute which led to the formation of CoAl and CoFe mixed oxides. DRM tests were carried out under atmospheric pressure at CH4/CO2 ratio of 1 and at the temperature of 400–700 °C. The results demonstrated that the CoFe catalyst has better resistance to carbon deposition than the CoAl catalyst while a little lower conversion of methane. It is also found that the CoFe catalyst was thermally more stable because Fe had a stronger interaction with CO3 2- than Al with CO3 2-. For the reduced CoAl catalyst, the DRM reaction exhibited CH4 and CO2 conversions of 66.4 % and 70.3 % at 700 °C while the CoFe catalyst showed 54.5 % and 60.2 %. The stability of the catalysts was determined after long-term experiments, and it was found that although the CoAl calcined and reduced catalyst was more active initially, it lost its activity after some time and got covered with carbon films. CoFe catalyst on the other hand was found to have better performance with less carbon deposition which was due to reverse water-gas shift reaction and oxygen species from FeOx for the removal of carbon. The enhanced catalytic performance of the CoFe catalyst was attributed to the development of CoFe alloy, which improved the catalyst stability against sintering and carbon deposition. This is in agreement with the results that increased the concentration of iron enhanced the formation of CO and helped in the desorption of carbonaceous deposits from the active sites to improve stability and activity during the DRM process. Aider et al.’s research underscores the significant influence of Fe in enhancing the thermal stability and carbon resistance of Co-based catalysts. The presence of FeOx species in the CoFe system plays a crucial role in the removal of carbon deposits via the reverse water-gas shift mechanism, which helps to mitigate the deactivation of active sites. The slightly lower methane conversion observed in the CoFe catalyst, as compared to CoAl, is offset by its superior resistance to coking and sintering, suggesting that Fe can enhance catalyst longevity under harsh DRM conditions. This finding paves the way for the next study, which examines how Ni-Ce mixed oxides can further optimize catalytic performance and stability in DRM. Osorio-Zabala et al. [265] employed Ni-Ce mixed oxides supported on cordierite monoliths as catalysts for the dry reforming of methane. These catalysts were prepared by coprecipitating Ni, Mg, Al, and Ce nitrates, washing and drying the obtained gel and then calcining it at 700 °C for 12 h with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The DRM reaction was carried out at 700 °C with the molar ratio of CH4 to CO2 at 1:1 and GHSV was 2655 h-1. The Ni-Ce mixed oxides without supports had lower conversion efficiency than the immobilized one; CH4 conversion of approximately 70–80 %, CO2 conversion of approximately 66–75 %, while the immobilized catalysts on cordierite monoliths had a slightly higher conversion efficiency of approximately 85–90 % for CH4 and 80–90 % for CO2. The enhancement in the performance of the Ni-Ce catalysts can be attributed to the promotional effect of Ce which increases the reducibility and stability of the active phase thus improving the H2/CO ratio and suppressing coke formation. CO2 adsorption was enhanced by Cerium and owing to redox activity, the catalyst activity and stability remains high over the long h of reaction, thus preventing formation of carbon. The role of cerium in the improvement of the catalytic properties of the Ni-Ce mixed oxides is further supported by the results from some of the characterization and analyses techniques. These results were further supported by the CO2-TPD analysis (Fig. 24 , C) which revealed the enhanced CO2 uptake further supporting the role of cerium in increasing the basicity and accessibility of the active adsorption sites. H2-TPR (Fig. 24A,B) studies also showed a decrease in reduction temperature indicating the enhanced reducibility that occurs due to redox cycling of Ce3+/Ce4+ which promotes the reduction of NiO to Ni. The results from Osorio-Zabala et al. highlight the impact of Ce in enhancing the redox properties of Ni-based LDH catalysts, particularly through the creation of oxygen vacancies that facilitate CO2 activation and reduce coke formation. The cordierite support further improves catalyst stability by preventing sintering and enhancing mass transfer properties, which are critical in maintaining high activity over extended operational periods. This exploration into monolith-supported catalysts offers valuable insight into how structural supports can be leveraged to optimize catalyst performance in DRM. the synthesis and characterization of the NiAl-LDH catalysts incorporating Mg and Zn for the dry reforming of biogas reported by Rosset et al. [266]. NiAl-LDH catalyst was first prepared with Ni/Al molar ratio of 2 by co-precipitation method at 50 °C and pH of 8. After calcination at 400 °C for 12 h the calcined material was dispersed in Mg(NO3)2 or Zn(NO3)2 solutions and was stirred at 50 °C for 24 h. These catalysts were then calcined at 600 °C to ensure that they were ready for use and this process took 6 h. This process resulted in well dispersed Ni metal particles especially when Ni2+ was replaced by Mg2+ into the hydrotalcite lattice. Calcination process was found to be of great importance in improving the catalytic properties of the material. The catalysts were exposed to calcination and reduction processes in different modes affecting the structure and performance of the catalysts. Ni-based catalysts were found to possess high activity and stability and possess significant conversion of CH4 and CO2. For example in 5 h TOS, The catalysts reconstructed with Zn and subsequently washed (Zn-W), achieved the highest CH4 and CO2 conversions of 73 % and 90 %, respectively and H2/CO of about two. The catalysts demonstrated high sintering stability at 700 °C, and Zn-based catalyst proved to be highly resistant to coke deposition. The enhancement in the catalytic performance of Zn-reconstructed catalyst is ascribed to its higher crystallinity and reducibility that enhances the reduction of NiO during H2 activation. Steffens et al. [267] investigated the applicability of lithium nickel aluminum (Li-Ni-Al) catalysts which are synthesized from layered double hydroxides for the DRM process. These catalysts were synthesized using co-precipitation of nickel, aluminium and lithium nitrates and then calcined at 600 °C. It was found, that lithium contributed to increase the basicity and thermal stability of the catalyst in comparison with the earlier developed hydrotalcite-based catalysts. While performing DRM reaction at 700 °C, the Li-Ni-Al catalyst with 5 wt. % Li was found to possess the higher basicity and strong basic sites which enhanced the CO2 adsorption and reduced the carbon formation resulting in the CH4 conversion of 67 % and CO2 conversion of over 90 %. H2-TPR and CO2-TPD measurements showed that lithium-modified catalyst had better interaction between nickel and the oxide support, which led to the formation of smaller Ni crystallite size, better thermal stability and less sintering effect that accounted for enhanced performance. Cheng et al. [268] synthesized a Ni-based hydrotalcite-like catalyst by the co-precipitation method, in which the metal ions originated from modified vermiculite waste solution and nickel ions doping. The preparation was done by ultrasonication of nickel nitrate hexahydrate with vermiculite waste and then by adding NaOH and Na2CO3 while stirring the solution until the pH=10. The DRM reaction was performed at 750 °C and the CH4/CO2 ratio was 1:1, and the GHSV was 36,000 mL/h/gcat where nickel was 15 % wt of the total catalyst weight and the conversion of CH4 and CO2 were 85.76 % and 84.42 % respectively after 24 h on the stream. This is due to the high dispersion and appropriate particle size of the catalyst and also the strong metal-support interaction in between Ni and support derived from vermiculite. The improved performance of the catalyst is scientifically justified by the increased surface area and pore volume, which enhances the adsorption of reactants and minimizes carbon deposition. The intimate contact between the Ni and Mg (Ni, Al) O phase improves the thermal stability of the prepared catalyst and its sintering resistance. Furthermore, impurities such as Fe and Ca in the waste vermiculite naturally enhance the redox nature and stability of the catalyst used. Niu et al. [269] applied a study on the application of hydrotalcite-like compound catalysts, with an emphasis on the kinetic evaluation and DFT simulations to discuss the catalytic reaction processes and the influence of different oxide dopants. The research combined Ni-based catalysts from hydrotalcite with small amounts of oxide additives, including CeO2, ZrO2 and ZnO. The kinetic studies and DFT calculations offered the understanding of the mechanism of the DRM process. The study showed that the forward turnover rate is not sensitive to the CO2 partial pressure, which means that the CHx dissociation step is rate determining for all the catalysts. The DFT calculations proved that the CO2 activation is energetically more favorable on the oxide supports than on the Ni surface. Among all the catalysts which have been investigated, CeO2 Ni showed the best activity concerning both stability and selectivity. It possessed the highest H2/CO ratio among all the tested temperatures and possessed the lowest apparent activation energy for CO2 activation. The enhancement in the performance is expected due to higher basicity and lower electronegativity of the oxide additives in the enhancement of the activation of CO2 and improved catalyst stability by the generation of reactive oxygen species which oxidize the carbons. The study concluded that the addition of oxide additives to Ni-based hydrotalcite-derived catalysts enhanced the performance of the DRM by enhancing CO2 activation and minimizing coking, leading to the increased lifespan of the catalyst. Other works in which used the LDH-based catalysts for the DRM reaction along with the reaction condition and acquired results are presented in Table 9 . As a summary to this section, Fig. 25 shows the main factors effecting the performance of the LDH- based catalysts in the DRM reaction (based on the works discussed). 6.4 Perovskite Perovskite materials have the chemical formula ABO3 (Fig. 26 ; A,B), where 'A' is a large cation (typically a rare earth or alkaline earth metal), and 'B' is a smaller cation (usually a transition metal). Perovskite-type materials, such as those with the Ruddlesden-Popper structure (Fig. 26;C,D), have formulas like A2BO4, where the structure contains alternating layers of perovskite ABO3 and A cation layers [284]. It is possible to replace A and/or B ions partially with other ions, which makes it possible to fine-tune thermal stability and catalytic properties of the material. Of these, LaNiO3 is the most investigated perovskite [285–290]. When reduced, LaNiO3 breaks down into Ni particles well distributed on the surface of lanthanum oxide support. The reduction process has effect on the size of the Ni particles and its activity as well. When the reactants are reduced prior to the addition of DRM, larger Ni clusters are produced with less activity while the addition of the reactants at room temperature before heating produces small clusters [291]. In situ XRD experiments have revealed that reduction of rhombohedral LaNiO3 occurs through formation of cubic LaNiO3, triclinic LaNiO2.7, and finally monoclinic LaNiO2.5, to form metallic Ni and monoclinic La2O2CO3 at 670 °C. This phase transforms into hexagonal La2O2CO3 at temperature above 700 °C and La2O3 at temperature above 750 °C [292]. The active phase in the case of DRM is usually metallic Ni in contact with monoclinic La2O2CO3 which adsorbs CO2 and stabilizes Ni particles. Reduction of LaNiO3 under hydrogen also undergoes similar phase sequence except that the formation of La2O2CO3 is important for the formation of coke resistant active phase. The steady-state tracing experiments have also revealed that La2O2CO3 plays the roles of one of the intermediate in CO production, stimulated by H species from CH4 decomposition [3,293–296]. The LaNiO3 perovskite exhibits significant activity for DRM, sometimes up to 100 h, although its performance is highly influenced by its morphology and synthesis method. The synthesis of perovskite materials generally requires high calcination temperatures, which result in low surface area values, usually around 10 m²/g. However, when activated either before or during the reaction, perovskite materials produce highly dispersed smaller metal particles on the mixed oxide structure, leading to high catalytic activity [297]. Different shapes, such as cubes, spheres, and rods, display varying behaviors; cubic shapes enhance conversion but also increase coke deposition, while spheres and rods offer remarkable stability due to the small size and high stability of exsolved Ni crystals formed through a three-step reduction process. Since LaNiO3 rapidly decomposes to Ni/La2O3, its stabilizing effect is relative. Efforts to stabilize the perovskite structure through partial Fe substitution at the B site have led to the formation of a La(NiFe)O3 structure that remains intact during DRM, enhancing long-term performance by providing stronger metal-support interaction and preventing sintering, although overall activity decreases due to lower Fe reducibility and reduced lattice oxygen mobility. Lattice oxygen acts as a reservoir to oxidize carbon, with its consumption and regeneration linked to the cycling oxidation states of neighboring ions. Provendier et al. [287] were among the first to observe that the addition of small amounts of Fe to LaNiO3 significantly enhanced stability (up to nearly 200 h) without affecting activity. Substituting cations can effectively control oxygen vacancies to ensure small metal crystallites and high oxygen mobility in the metal oxide. Substituting either the A-site or B-site in perovskite structures such as LaNiO3 has a profound effect on the formation of the capable catalyst. Substituting A-site cation, for instance, by Ce or Pr in place of lanthanum, minimizes carbon deposition and increases the catalyst's stability. B-site substitution is the replacement of Ni with other metals such as Fe, Co, or Cu, which enhances metal distribution and electronic characteristics, thus enhancing catalytic performance and coking endurance. Substituting La with Ce or Pr, even in small amounts, prevents carbon formation and enhances activity, although the degree of substitution significantly impacts the outcome [298]. Kumar Yadav et al. [299] studied a number of perovskite-type catalysts for the dry reforming of methane and prepared them by using silica supported alumina and magnesia. The catalysts were synthesized through sol-gel process by using 40LaNi0.75Zr0.25-xCexO3/SiO2 with x ranging from 0 to 0.25. The preparation stage involved the process of dissolving of La(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O, zirconium (IV) propoxide and cerium nitrate in distilled water and then the citric acid was added. The above mixture was mixed, gelled, dried and then calcined at 1073 K for 3 h. The site substitution was done in the B-site with cerium and zirconium, which increased the oxygen mobility and storage capacity leading to the improved catalytic activity and stability due to hindering of carbon deposition. The catalysts with the composition of 40LaNi0.75Zr0.20Ce0.05O3/8MgO-SiO2 demonstrated the highest conversion rates of methane and carbon dioxide. This composition maintained a near unity H2/CO ratio for the first 10 h of operation of this composition. The conversions of CH4 and CO2 enhanced with the incorporation of ceria and reduced with the incorporation of more ceria beyond the optimum amount, thereby illustrating the strong effect of ceria content on the catalyst performance. The enhanced performance of the 40LaNi0.75Zr0.20Ce0.05O3/8MgO-SiO2 catalyst is due to the better dispersion of nickel oxide, higher surface area and formation of NiO-MgO solid solutions. These modifications also enhanced the stability of the catalyst and reduced the tendency of carbon formation. In order to explore the effect of replacement of other elements in LaNiO3 perovskite, Georgiadis et al. [300] prepared perovskite-type LaNiO3-based catalysts with the incorporation of Sm, Pr and Ce by citrate sol-gel process. After the preparation, the catalyst calcined at a temperature of 400 °C for 1 h and 900 °C for 4 h. The DRM reaction was conducted at 750 °C, GHSV of 200,000 mL h-1 g-1 and to ensure the stability of the catalyst, long term test of 18 h was performed. As can be seen from Fig. 27 , the LNO (LaNiO3) catalyst provided the highest conversion rates of CH4 (52 %) and CO2 (85 %) and Sm and Pr-modified catalysts (LSNO and LPNO) demonstrated higher stability and low coke formation (Fig. 27, Left). The B-site substitution, wherein Ni is partially replaced by other metals, was intended to address carbon deposition problems. The Sm and Pr modifications resulted in enhanced catalytic stability as a result of decreased crystallinity of deposited coke and enhanced metal-support interaction. These substitutions also improved the movement of oxygen, which helps in the process of gasification of coke deposits, and hence increased performance. In terms of the catalytic performance, the catalysts were found to exhibit varying performance. LCNO catalyst, which was Ce-modified, had the lowest activity, due to the weak formation of perovskite phase and higher crystallinity of coke. The LSNO and LPNO catalysts performed better than the other catalysts, probably because of better dispersion of the metal and strong interaction between the metal and the support (Fig. 27, Right). These improvements were further supported by experimental and modeling studies, where it was found that physicochemical properties have a direct bearing on catalytic performance. The effect of Zr modification on LaNiO3 was investigated by Sagar et al. [301]. They prepared LaNixZr1-xO3 (0 ≤ x ≤ 1) catalysts by sol-gel method. This process included the preparation of nitrate salts (lanthanum nitrate, nickel nitrate and zirconyl nitrate) dissolving in hot propionic acid and stirring, refluxing and drying the solids to form a resin followed by calcination of the solids at 800 °C for 4 h. Such a preparation method allowed for the formation of either La-Zr pyrochlore or La-Ni perovskite phases depending on the Ni ratio to other elements. The work was centered on B-site substitution whereby Ni partially substituted for Zr in the perovskite structure. The main novelty of this paper is the confirmation of phase transformation from La-Zr pyrochlore to La-Ni perovskite with the increase in the Ni content, which improves the catalyst's activity in the DRM. The catalysts were tested for DRM at 800 °C, at a GHSV of 28,800 h-1. Comparing with the other catalysts, LaNi0.8Zr0.2O3 has the highest activity with the CO2 and CH4 conversion of 50 % and 37 %, respectively. The long term stability tests revealed that the LaNi0.8Zr0.2O3 catalyst was stable up to 10 h of the test, although CO2 conversion was found to decrease after 4 h because of side reactions such as RWGS. The improved performance of the LaNi0.8Zr0.2O3 catalyst can be attributed to the high dispersion of Ni species on the La2O3-ZrO2 support which increases the catalytic activity and coke resistance. The phase transformation from pyrochlore to perovskite enhances the reducibility of the catalyst and results in better dispersion of the active Ni sites on the support and improved high-temperature stability. Another research work done by Cao et al. [302] was a detailed research on the La2NiO4 perovskite catalysts. According to their results, La2NiO4 is highly stable and active in the DRM reaction, while NiO and NiO/La2O3 catalysts suffer from a large activity decline because of sintering. The enhanced performance of La2NiO4 can be explained by high dispersion of Ni0 particles on the La2O3 support due to perovskite decomposition. They found out that 850 °C was the most suitable temperature for minimizing carbon deposition and maximizing the reaction stability and, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 after 10 h time on stream were 96.9 % and 97.8 %, respectively. They also focused on the effect of the atmosphere on the regeneration performance of La2NiO4 to which they concluded that steam was the most effective in removing carbon deposit, air and CO2. This research is useful in advancing the knowledge and application of perovskite-type catalysts in DRM, which focuses on high dispersion and strong metal-support interaction for better catalytic performance and stability. In a work by Shahnazi and Firoozi [303], the LaNi1-xMnxO3 catalyst has been employed. This perovskite was synthesised by using glycine assisted ultrasonic spray pyrolysis (USP). In preparation, La(NO3)3⋅6H2O, Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O, Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O and glycine were first dissolved in water and atomized using ultrasonic nebulizers. The reaction was done in a two-chamber furnace; the drying chamber at 150 °C and the reaction chamber at 1000 °C. The collected powders were then dried at a temperature of 100 °C for a period of 24 h. For the sample without Mn (LNM0), further calcination process at 900 °C for 4 h was necessary to form the perovskite structure. However, for Mn-substituted samples (LNM40 and LNM100), there was direct formation of perovskite structure at the time of pyrolysis and there was no need of calcination. As for the substitutions, this work analyzed both A-site substitution and B-site substitution, with the latter being the partial substitution of Ni with Mn. This substitution enhanced the structural stability of the catalyst and minimized the formation of Carbon deposits. The glycine-assisted spray pyrolysis enhanced the specific surface area, which is more than the sol-gel method, and changed the morphology to exhibit better catalytic properties and coke resistance. The major conclusions revealed that the Mn-substituted catalyst possessed the enhanced activity in the DRM compared to the non-substituted one. The conversion rates of CH4 and CO2 were improved and for the sample LNM40-G25, CH4 conversion was 84 % and CO2 conversion was found to be higher than other samples. The DRM reactions were performed in the temperature range of 600–800 °C, GHSV=15 L gcat -1 h-1 with the long-term tests at 700 °C for 20 h. The results from above work was affirmed by another recent study done by Bhaskaran et al. [290]. Although LaNiO3 is the most studied perovskite structure in developing a suitable catalyst for the DRM reaction,there are other perovskites that have been studied in this area. Qiong Rao et al. [304] studied the application of Ni-doped Fe2O3/La0.8Sr0.2FeO3 (LSF) as an oxygen carrier in a chemical looping dry reforming (CLDRM) process for methane. The catalyst was prepared by synthesizing the material by doping 20 wt. % Ni into Fe2O3 and LSF and then calcining it. The Ni-Fe2O3/LSF catalyst was characterized for its activity in a fixed bed reactor and its stability in 160 cycles of the reaction. The study was confined to B-site substitution in perovskite structure that enhanced the reduction capability and reduced carbon formation. Long term catalyst stability and activity test were performed at an optimal temperature of 800 °C with GHSV of 40 mL/min. The methane conversion was up to 99 % with nearly full CO selectivity to give syngas with H2/CO ratio of approximately two. Yao et al. [305] investigated the performance and stability of exsolved Ni-Fe alloy catalysts for DRM. They used a double-layer perovskite catalyst, PrBaMn1.6Ni0.4–2xFe2xO5+δ, synthesized via an improved sol-gel method. The conversions of the reactants varied with the composition of the catalysts. For instance, the E-Ni0.2 (contains nickel as the primary metal component in the double-layer perovskite structure and 0.2 indicates nickel proportion in the B-site of the perovskite lattice) catalyst showed an initial high CH4 conversion but suffered from rapid deactivation due to coking. In contrast, E-Ni0.15Fe0.05 exhibited a slightly lower initial CH4 conversion but maintained its activity over a prolonged period (40 h), demonstrating superior long-term stability. The CO2 conversion was higher than CH4 conversion for all catalysts, with the E-Ni0.15Fe0.05 catalyst maintaining a high CO2 conversion throughout the test duration. From XPS analysis Fig. 28 ), for P-Ni0.15Fe0.05(P refers to initial form of the catalyst before any exsolution process), only divalent Ni2+ peaks were observed in the fresh catalyst, but after reduction, metallic Ni0 peaks appeared, indicating the presence of reduced nickel. Similarly, the Fe element showed mixed oxidation states of Fe2+ and Fe3+ before reduction, with a small part reduced to Fe0 post-reduction. This confirms the formation of a Ni-Fe alloy, which contributes to the enhanced stability and resistance to coking. An overview on other works done with perovskites structure catalysts for the DRM reaction is provided in Table 10 . Perovskite-catalyzed DRM follows distinct reaction pathways that contrast with traditional Ni-based catalysts. The DRM process with perovskites works through intrinsic oxygen mobility along with redox properties by implementing the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. The catalyst function consists of four sequential Mars-van Krevelen steps that use B-site metals for CH₄ dissociation into CH₃*, CH₂*, CH* and C* species followed by oxygen vacancies and A-site base cation activation of CO₂ and oxygen migration to oxidize carbon deposits (C* → CO) and end with CO₂ dissociation to regenerate vacancies. The self-regenerative cycle helps to understand why perovskite systems demonstrate better coke resistance than conventional catalysts [306,307]. The catalytic performance of perovskites depends strongly on their atomic geometry together with their electronic structure features. The octahedral B-site cation arrangement produces distinctive d-orbital splitting which controls adsorption energy and the Goldschmidt factor controls the perovskite structure's shape [308]. The catalytic properties reach their optimum when the octahedral tilting is optimal at values of 0.75 < t < 1.0. The ability of B-site cations to change their oxidation state provides multiple electronic states which benefits both CH₄ and CO₂ activation through lowered reaction barriers [309]. The arrangement pattern of oxygen vacancies within perovskites determines the carbon gasification rates because ordered vacancies at the A-site deficiency boost oxygen mobility beyond random vacancy distributions. The development of advanced compositional approaches goes beyond basic ABO₃ structures to optimize DRM efficiency. The ordered arrangement of different B-site cations in dual perovskites (A₂BB'O₆) creates synergistic effects through La₂NiFeO₆ which enhances Ni-Fe electron transfer for both CH₄ activation and carbon oxidation. The oxygen mobility of Ruddlesden-Popper phases ( An+1BnX3n+1 ) with alternating perovskite and rock-salt layers leads to exceptional carbon deposition suppression. The combined doping of Sr²⁺/Ba²⁺ at A-sites together with Co/Fe/Cu at B-sites adjusts electronic properties and metal-oxygen bond strength and basicity which leads to superior CO₂ adsorption alongside preserved CH₄ activation capabilities. Perovskite behavior during reaction conditions represents a vital factor which researchers typically ignore. When conditions become reducing B-site cations can migrate to the surface where they form superior sintering-resistant metallic nanoparticles that anchor to the perovskite matrix. The partial transformation of crystal structure produces new metal-oxide connections which establish unique locations for reaction intermediate molecules to bind. The controlled phase segregation process leads to advantageous reactions where LaNiO₃ decomposes into La₂O₃ and metallic Ni under DRM conditions which produces an integrated structure that combines both CH₄ activation ability and improved CO₂ adsorption. Perovskites integrated with conventional supports generate hybrid systems that demonstrate improved characteristics. When perovskite-CeO₂ interfaces enable oxygen exchange between phases they boost the oxygen mobility and carbon gasification rates by 70 % relative to standalone components [310,311]. When perovskite-modified zeolites are combined they offer both the zeolite's shape selectivity and the perovskite's catalytic activity to control product distribution. The development of perovskite catalyst systems stands as a leading frontier in DRM catalyst evolution because researchers can now purposefully design geometric and electronic properties to control reaction pathways. Future research needs to employ advanced characterization tools for studying carbon resistance mechanisms at the atomic level and create scalable synthesis methods for complex perovskite structures and develop integrated processes for DRM with other CO₂ conversion reactions while using computational screening based on machine learning for electronic property optimization of new compositions. 7 Conclusion and future perspective This review has systematically surveyed the advancement in developing catalysts for Dry Reforming of Methane (DRM), which is a process of converting greenhouse gases, CH4 and CO2, into valuable syngas. DRM, not only deals with the increased concentration of CO2, but also mitigating the highly potent environmental impact of methane. Catalysts in the DRM process can get deactivated because of carbon formation or sintering. Some of the factors include temperature, pressure, concentration of the reactants, and the like may affect catalyst deactivation. Furthermore, the incorrect choice of the ratio of the reactants or high content of steam can cause the formation of carbon and the deactivation of the catalyst. Carbon deposition causes a decrease in the surface area of the catalyst, a decrease in the adsorption of reactants and the blocking of active sites, which leads to a decrease in catalytic activity and selectivity. To address these problems, researches initiated extensive research efforts to designing a capable catalyst for this reaction. The review has methodically categorized all these catalysts into different groups with more emphasis on nickel based catalyst due to their efficiency and economic viability. There is a balanced trade-off between cost-effectiveness and operational efficiency by nickel-cobalt and nickel-cerium combinations indicating that they will be particularly promising when used together. This was confirmed by better catalytic activities as well as stability demonstrated through several experimental works. Ceria and alumina are advanced supports, regarding how they can improve dispersion as well as stabilization of active metal sites leading to prolonged catalyst life. Such materials help enhance the thermal properties among others for improved resistance under severe operating conditions usually encountered during DRM processes. Between all catalyst systems discussed in this review, Mg-O based solid solution and pervoskite structures has led into the best lifespan without deactivation up to 200 h which was untouchable for many catalyst designs. The factors involving in catalyst design for DRM are portrayed in Fig. 29 . In future studies, catalysts should be developed with a clear understanding of reaction principles as well as control over their properties such as support matrix morphology and basicity, metal dispersion, metal-support interactions, and oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, it is necessary to specify standards of evaluating catalytic activity for equal comparison between different research institutions and companies. Since CO2 and CH4 conversion rates vary depending on such parameters as reactant gas ratios, space velocity, bed length and catalyst amount; test conditions should remain constant during different catalyst tests. All the conversions mentioned in this review refer to the long term stability tests in the outlet stream unless it stated otherwise. The motive behind that was to have some uniform way of evaluation of catalyst performance thus identifying which catalytic system can be used for industrial purposes in future. Future DRM catalyst development are anticipated to come from interdisciplinary research which merges in-situ characterization techniques with computational modeling and precise synthesis methods. Rational design strategies will become possible through the capability to observe catalyst evolution during reactions while establishing atomic-level structure-performance relationships. The coupling of DRM technology with bi-reforming or tri-reforming systems provides a flexible and robust framework to convert greenhouse gases effectively through different feedstock compositions and operating parameters. The application of computational tools with Machine learning could potentially enhance the rate at which the best catalyst composition and arrangement are identified. Machine learning models is a powerful and new tool that can predict the outcomes of catalyst performance under various conditions and thus can replace the time-consuming physical experiments. Further, there is always a challenge of developing these catalysts to operate at lower temperatures, which would greatly reduce energy consumption and cost of operations. The investigation discussed in Section 6 on alternative materials such as layered double hydroxides, perovskites, and metal-organic frameworks may yield catalysts which would operate well at lower temperatures with improved selectivity and durability. The change from lab to industrial scale demands optimization of catalysts and matching them with reactors; however, this remains the biggest problem in terms of scalability however, for these findings to be useful in industries, pilot studies and long-term performance evaluations need to be carried out to determine if the bimetallic or the advanced support material-based catalysts are sustainable or not. In conclusion, the development of the DRM catalysts discussed in this review not only demonstrates the great potential of this technology to change the energy and environmental situation in the world but also points out the directions that require further research and development. With the help of further integration of interdisciplinary approaches and new ideas, DRM technology can be improved and perfected, thus contributing to the creation of a more energy-efficient world. coredata.dc:description: The increased global energy demand resulting from population growth and the use of fossil fuels has led to environmental issues such as greenhouse gas emissions. This review focuses on Dry Reforming of Methane (DRM) technology that has the potential to convert methane and carbon dioxide (two major greenhouse gases) into syngas which is a base material for various chemical and fuel products. It is virtually impossible to perform the DRM reaction on an industrial scale if there is no efficient, low-cost and highly resistant to deactivation catalyst. This review gives information on the recent development in efficient and robust DRM catalysts following a brief discussion on the thermodynamics and the mechanisms involved in the DRM process. The paper also classifies the main types of catalysts based on the supporting material for supported catalysts and reduced solid solution catalysts in addition to identifying significant performance improvement factors. It is to give an insight into the catalytic interactions and to help in the improvements of the catalyst stability and activity concerning issues such as coking and sintering. In the last part of the article, the important parameters affecting the catalyst design discussed and the authors’ opinion on the future advancements in this field have been portrayed.
coredata.dc:title: Recent progress in catalysts development of dry reforming of methane process: Review of active phases and supports of catalyst
